xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: CIS Google ChromeOS Benchmark

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This document provides prescriptive guidance for establishing a secure configuration posture for Google ChromeOS devices. This guide was tested against Google ChromeOS v128. To obtain the latest version of this guide, please visit http://benchmarks.cisecurity.org
. If you have questions, comments, or have identified ways to improve this guide, please write us at feedback@cisecurity.org
.

IMPORTANT NOTE:
This Benchmark assumes that Google ChromeOS devices are managed via Google Workspace.

This Benchmark has high-level sections based on various security related concerns (Enforced Defaults, Privacy, etc.). It includes specific recommendations from both the Google Chrome and Google Workspace CIS Benchmarks that also apply to Google ChromeOS.
Many of the settings specified in this Benchmark are also the default settings. These are specified for the following reasons:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: The default (Unset) setting may have the same effect as what is prescribed, but they allow the user to change these settings at any time. Actually configuring the browser setting to the prescribed value will prevent the user from changing it.

Many organizations want the ability to scan systems for Benchmark compliance and configuration drift using CIS (CIS-CAT) or CIS-certified third party tools ( CIS Vendor Partners
). Having these settings specified in the Benchmark allows for this.

xhtml:h2.xhtml:strong: Viewing the Resulting Policies in ChromeOS

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
These "Policy" settings can be viewed on a managed Google ChromeOS device directly by typing chrome://policy/
directly into the Google Chrome address box, or through Google Workspace, https://admin.google.com
.
For more information on Google ChromeOS management, visit https://chromeos.google/products/device-management/

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Items in this profile intend to:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: be the starting baseline for most organizations;
be practical and prudent;
provide a clear security benefit; and
not inhibit the utility of the technology beyond acceptable means.

xccdf:Profile.xccdf:title: Level 2 (L2) - High Security/Sensitive Data Environment (limited functionality)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This profile extends the "Level 1 (L1)" profile. Items in this profile exhibit one or more of the following characteristics:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: are intended for environments or use cases where security is more critical than manageability and usability;
may negatively inhibit the utility or performance of the technology; and
limit the ability of remote management/access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Note: Implementation of Level 2 requires that both Level 1 and Level 2 settings are applied.

Value.title: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'
Value.description: This value is used in Rule: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API' for the registry data type

Value.title: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'
Value.description: This value is used in Rule: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API' for the registry value

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The Directory section of the Google Workspace Admin Console.
User defined in this domain and their permissions.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure more than one Super Admin account exists

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Having more than one Super Admin account is needed primarily so that a single point of failure can be avoided. Also, for larger organizations, having multiple Super Admins can be useful for workload balancing purposes.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: From a security point of view, having only a single Super Admin Account can be problematic if this user were unavailable for an extended period of time. Also, Super Admin accounts should never be shared amongst multiple users.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Create at least one additional account with a Super Admin role.

NOTE:
A new account should be created vs adding this role to an existing account since Administration tasks should be done through separate Admin accounts.
Impact:
There should be no user impact, but Administrators should have a normal (low privilege) and an Administrative (high privilege) account.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure no more than 4 Super Admin accounts exist

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Having more than one Super Admin account is needed primarily so that a single point of failure can be avoided, but having too many should be avoided.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: From a security point of view, having a large number of Super Admin accounts is a bad practice. In general, all users should be assigned the least privileges needed to do their job. This includes Administrators since not everyone that needs to perform certain administrative functions needs to be a Super Admin. Google Workspaces provides many predefined Administration roles and also allows the creation of Custom Roles with very granular permission selection.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Reduce the number of accounts with a "Super Admin" role.
Impact:
There should be no user impact, but Administrators should have a normal (low privilege) and an Administrative (high privilege) account.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure Super Admin accounts are used only for Super Admin activities

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Super Admin accounts have access to all features in the Google Admin console and Admin API and can manage every aspect of your organization's account. Super Admins also have full access to all users' calendars and event details.

It is recommended to give each super administrator two accounts: one for their Super Admin account, and a second account for daily activities. Users should only sign in to a Super Admin account to perform Super Admin tasks, such as setting up 2-Step Verification (2SV), managing billing and user licenses, or helping another admin recover their account. Super administrators should use a separate, non-admin account for day-to-day activities.
Super Admins should sign in as needed to do specific tasks and then sign out. Leaving Super Admin accounts signed in can increase exposure to phishing attacks.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Use the Super Admin account only when needed. Delegate administrator tasks to user accounts with limited admin roles. Use the least privilege approach, where each user has access to only the resources and tools needed for their typical tasks. For example, you could grant an admin permissions to create user accounts and reset passwords, but not let them delete user accounts.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
For every Super Admin
that is also a Delegated admin
account, either create a Delegated admin
account for the user or elevate their existing non-admin account to a Delegated admin
account.
Impact:
Super Admin users will have to switch accounts as well as utilize login/logout functionality when performing administrative tasks.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The Chrome configuration panel is used to manage ChromeOS and ChromeOS devices.

The Devices
section in Google Workspace allows you to verify your enrolled ChromeOS devices as well as enroll new ChromeOS devices. Administrators should regularly audit the Devices
and make sure they are part of your organization's fleet of ChromeOS devices.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Review Devices Periodically

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
All ChromeOS devices that are managed by your organization are listed in the Devices
section of Google Workspace. It is a best practice to periodically audit the list for any unknown devices as well as remove any devices that are no longer in service.
If any unknown devices are found, they should be investigated.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Performing a periodic review of connected devices ensures only permitted and required devices can access organizational data or resources.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator
Ensure all listed devices have been properly vetted and authorized by the appropriate personnel

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user or admin.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The section of Google Workspace where enrollment tokens for ChromeOS are created and stored.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure Any Unused Enrollment Tokens Are Revoked

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: An organization should not have any unused enrollment tokens.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Revoking unused enrollment tokens keeps them from being used on unknown devices.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user of admin.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The setting section contains both configurations for the User & browser
section, Devices
section, and Managed guest session settings
section.

The User & browser
section is where Chrome and ChromeOS shared configurations exist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Maximum user session length' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This control sets the length of time that a session can run before the user is logged out and the session is terminated. The user is shown in the system tray how much time is remaining before they will be automatically logged out.
The values are between 1 minute to 1440 minutes. If no value is set, then the system observes an unlimited session time.

While 60 minutes is a good operating baseline for the session, depending on your organization this may vary. For example, in K-12 a 24 hour (1440 minutes) session might be the best setting. Use the best setting for your organization's needs.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting a session length allows Chrome OS to not have a user session continuously signed in, thus preventing unauthorized access by someone other than the user.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under General
, select Maximum user session length

Set Maximum session length
to your organization's parameters

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There could be impacts to the user if they are unaware of, or are not actively checking, the session timer. They might be logged out unexpectedly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Custom terms of service' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: An access warning informs the user that the system is reserved for authorized use only, and that the use of the system may be monitored.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An access warning may reduce a casual attacker's tendency to target the system. Access warnings may also aid in the prosecution of an attacker by evincing the attacker's knowledge of the system's private status, acceptable use policy, and authorization requirements.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under General
, select Custom terms of service

Select a .txt
or .text
file from your local device that contains your organization's custom terms of service

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If users are not informed of their responsibilities, unapproved activities may occur. Users that are not approved for access may take the lack of a warning banner as implied consent to access.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Display password button' Is Set to 'Do not show the display password button on the login and lock screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This configuration controls whether or not the user can choose to have their passwords displayed in clear text.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Removing the ability for users to display their password may cause the occasional login issue, but can also stop the possibility of someone shoulder-surfing a password.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under General
, select Display password button

Set Display password button
to Do not show the display password button on the login and lock screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Having this enabled may cause users to enter incorrect credentials because they cannot verify if they typed in the correct password.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Task Manager' Is Set to 'Block users from ending processes with the Chrome task manager'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The Task Manager in ChromeOS allows the user to kill any current processes running.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the Task Manager is enabled, a user can kill any running task including those that your organization uses to manage the user of the device. Disabling that functionality removes that possibility.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Apps and extensions
select Users & browsers
Set to Block users from ending processes with the Chrome task manager

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If a task is no longer responding, the user would have to turn the device off and back on to kill that task.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Manifest v2 extension availability' Is Set to 'Enable force-installed manifest v2 extensions on the sign-in screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting controls extension management settings for Google Chrome, specifically v2 extensions. This policy setting is being sunsetted as Google develops the Manifest v3, but that rollout is currently postponed.
The policy can be configured to:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Default (0): Default browser behavior
Disabled (1): Manifest v2 is disabled
Enabled (2): Manifest v2 is enabled
Forced Only (3): Manifest v2 is enabled for forced extensions only

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Apply Host-based Firewalls or Port Filtering

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this to Forced Only will not allow users to install any additional v2 extensions, and all existing, non-forced, v2 extensions will be disabled.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Manifest v2 extension availability

Set Configuration
to Enable force-installed manifest v2 extensions on the sign-in screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users that use extensions regularly will have a set of them blocked, which will change their user experience.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Site isolation' is set to 'Require Site Isolation for all websites, as well as any origins below'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls if every website will load into its own process.

Disabled
(0): Doesn't turn off site isolation, but it lets users opt out.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Backups Have At least One Non-Continuously Addressable Destination

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Chrome will load each website in its own process. Even if a site bypasses the same-origin policy, the extra security will help stop the site from stealing your data from another website.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Site isolation

Set Configuration
to Require Site Isolation for all websites, as well as any origins below

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If the policy is enabled, each site will run in its own process which will cause the system to use more memory. You might want to look at the Enable Site Isolation for specified origins
policy setting to get the best of both worlds isolation and limited impact for users by using Enable Site Isolation for specified origins
with a list of the sites you want to isolate.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Password manager' is Explicitly Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has a built-in password manager to store passwords for users. Chrome will use local authentication to allow users to gain access to these passwords.

The recommended state for this setting is: Explicitly set to Enabled
(1) or Disabled
(0) based on the organization's needs.

NOTE:
If you choose to Enable this setting, please review Disable synchronization of data with Google
and ensure this setting is configured to meet organizational requirements.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
The Google Chrome password manager is Enabled
by default and each organization should review and determine if they want to allow users to store passwords in the Browser. If another solution is used instead of the built-in Chrome option then an organization should configure the setting to Disabled
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Password manager

Set Configuration
to Always allow use of password manager
or Never allow use of password manager

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Organizationally dependent.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure Advanced Protection Program is configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enable Google's Advanced Protection Platform for all users and prevent the use of security codes where applicable.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Sophisticated phishing tactics can trick the most savvy users into giving their sign-in credentials to attackers. Advanced Protection requires you to use a security key, which is a hardware device or special software on your phone used to verify your identity, to sign in to your Google Account. Unauthorized users wont be able to sign in without your security key, even if they have your username and password.

The Advanced Protection Program includes a curated group of high-security policies that are applied to enrolled accounts. Additional policies may be added to the Advanced Protection Program to ensure the protections are current.
Advanced Protection allows you to apply all of these protections at once, and override similar settings you may have configured manually. These policies include:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Strong authentication with security keys
Use of security codes with security keys (as needed)
Restrictions on third-party access to account data
Deep Gmail scans
Google Safe Browsing protections in Chrome (when users are signed into Chrome using the same identity as their Advanced Protection Program identity)
Account recovery through admin

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To verify this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Enrollment - Allow users to enroll in the Advanced Protection Program
, set Enable user enrollment
to selected
for the desired organizational unit or group

Under Security Codes
, set Do not allow users to generate security codes
to selected
for the desired organizational unit or group

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: You need your security key when you sign in for the first time on a computer, browser, or device. If you stay signed in, you may not be asked to use your security key the next time you log in.
Limits third-party app access to your data, puts stronger checks on suspicious downloads, and tightens account recovery security to help prevent unauthorized access.
Android: With an Android 7.0+ phone, you can enroll in a few taps by registering your phones built-in security key.

iPhone: If you have an iPhone running iOS 10.0+, install the Google Smart Lock
app to register your security key first, then enroll.
Two security keys are required for added assurance. If one key is lost or damaged, users can use the second key to regain account access.

You can use the Advanced Protection Program with accounts that federate from an IdP using SAML. When users with these accounts enroll in the Advanced Protection Program, well require security key use after the user signs in on the IdP. Note that SAML users can select Remember the device to avoid challenges on a browser or device.

Before allowing users to generate security codes, carefully evaluate if your organization needs them. Using security keys with security codes increases the risk of phishing. However, if your organization has important workflows where security keys cant be used directly, enabling security codes for those situations may help improve your security posture overall.

xhtml:p.xhtml:strong: Using 'Sign in with Google' with other apps and services

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: You can still sign into apps and services with Google. If they request access to your Gmail or Drive data, access is denied.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Geolocation' is set to 'Do not allow sites to detect users' geolocation'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome supports tracking a user's physical location using GPS, data about nearby Wi-Fi access points or cellular signal sites/towers (even if youre not using them), and your computers IP.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0, same as 3)

Allow sites to track the users' physical location
(1)

Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location
(2)

Ask whenever a site wants to track the users' physical location
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: From a privacy point of view it is not desirable to submit indicators regarding the location of the device, since the processing of this information cannot be determined. Furthermore, this may leak information about the network infrastructure around the device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Geolocation

Set Configuration
to Do not allow sites to detect users' geolocation

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, chrome will no longer send data about nearby Wi-Fi access points or cellular signal sites/towers (even if youre not using them), and your computers IP address to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Web Authentication requests on sites with broken TLS certificates' Is Set to 'Do not allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting controls the WebAuthn API and its interaction with sites that have a broken TLS certificate. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Do not allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates.
Enabled (1): Allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for AllowWebAuthnWithBrokenTlsCerts
is not changed from the default, it will behave as it is disabled.xempt.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will block the ability to authenticate to any website that does not have a valid TLS certificate since the identity of the site cannot be verified.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Web Authentication requests on sites with broken TLS certificates

Set Configuration
to Do not allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no user impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Incognito mode' is set to 'Disallow incognito mode'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Specifies whether the user may open pages in Incognito mode in Google Chrome. The possible values are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Incognito mode disabled
(1)

Incognito mode forced
(2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled: Incognito mode disabled
(1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Incognito mode in Chrome gives you the choice to browse the internet without your activity being saved to your browser or device.

Allowing users to use the browser without any information being saved can hide evidence of malicious behaviors. This information may be important for a computer investigation, and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Incognito mode

Set Configuration
to Disallow incognito mode

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to initiate Incognito mode for Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Browser history' is set to 'Always save browser history'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome is configured to save the browser history.
The recommended state for this setting is: Always save browser history

NOTE:
This setting will preserve browsing history that could contain a user's personal browsing history. Please make sure that this setting is in compliance with organizational policies.

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Browser history shall be saved as it may contain indicators of compromise.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Browser history

Set Configuration
to Always save browser history

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Insecure hashes in TLS handshakes' Is Set to 'Do not allow insecure hashes in TLS handshakes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to allow legacy or insecure hashes during the TLS handshake. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Do Not Allow Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes
Enabled (1): Allow Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for InsecureHashesInTLSHandshakesEnabled
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy to disabled will block Google Chrome from using insecure hashes. Using insecure, or legacy, hashes could allow sensitive data to be exposed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Insecure hashes in TLS handshakes

Set Configuration
to Do not allow insecure hashes in TLS handshakes

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users would be blocked from visiting sites that do not support more secure hashes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'PIN auto-submit' Is Set to 'Disable PIN auto-submit on the lock and login screen'

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator
Set to Disable PIN auto-submit on the lock and login screen

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Clear browser history' Is Set to 'Do not allow clearing history in settings menu'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can delete the browser and download history using the clear browsing data menu.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
Even when this setting is disabled, the browsing and download history aren't guaranteed to be retained. Users can edit or delete the history database files directly, and the browser itself may remove (based on expiration period) or archive any or all history items at any time.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If users can delete websites they have visited or files they have downloaded, it will be easier for them to hide evidence that they have visited unauthorized or malicious sites.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Clear browser history

Set Configuration
to Do not allow clearing history in settings menu

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, browsing and download history cannot be deleted by using the clear browsing data menu.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'File/directory picker without user gesture' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This setting controls the ability for showOpenFilePicker()
, showSaveFilePicker()
, and showDirectoryPicker()
web APIs to be called without user interaction.

If the value for FileOrDirectoryPickerWithoutGestureAllowedForOrigins
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is disabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Apply Host-based Firewalls or Port Filtering

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Setting this policy would allow the URLs selected to call the showOpenFilePicker()
, showSaveFilePicker()
, and showDirectoryPicker()
web APIs without any user gesture/interaction. This policy does not need to be set for this reason.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select File/directory picker without user gesture
Remove all URLs from Allow file or directory picker APIs to be called without prior user gesture

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Disabling this policy should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allowed certificate transparency URLs' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can specify URLs/hostnames for which Certificate Transparency will not be enforced. If this setting is disabled, no URLs are excluded from Certificate Transparency requirements.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificates that are required to be disclosed via Certificate Transparency shall be treated for all URLs as untrusted if they are not disclosed according to the Certificate Transparency policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Allowed certificate transparency URLs
Remove all URLs from Allowed certificate transparency URLs

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'TLS encrypted ClientHello' Is 'Enable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for using Encrypted ClientHello (ECH). ECH is an extension to TLS and encrypts the initial handshake with a website that can only be decrypted by that website. Google Chrome may, or may not, use ECH based on 3 factors: server support, HTTPS DNS record availability, or rollout status. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment
Enabled (1): Enable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for EncryptedClientHelloEnabled
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt All Sensitive Information in Transit

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Previously all handshakes were in the open and could expose sensitive information, like the name of the website to which you are connecting. Setting this policy will allow Google Chrome to use an encrypted hello, or handshake, with a website where it is supported, thus not exposing sensitive information.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select TLS encrypted ClientHello

Set Configuration
to Enable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Online revocation checks' is set to 'Perform online OCSP/CRL checks'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome performs revocation checking for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. If Google Chrome is unable to obtain revocation status information, such certificates will be treated as revoked ('hard-fail').

Disabled
: Google Chrome uses existing online revocation-checking settings.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificates shall always be validated.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Online revocation checks

Set Configuration
to Perform online OCSP/CRL checks

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A revocation check will be performed for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. if the OCSP server goes down, then this will hard-fail and prevent browsing to those sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Google online login frequency' Is Set to '0'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: During login, Google ChromeOS can authenticate against an online server or by using an offline cached password. This configuration sets the frequency of forced online sign-ins on the login screen for users signing into their ChromeOS device without SAML single sign-on (SSO).

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Each time users sign out after the set frequency period, they must go through the online sign-in flow.

When users sign in online, they use the Google identity service. By forcing users to regularly sign in, you provide additional security for organizations that require 2-Factor Authentication or Multi-Factor Authentication.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set to Force online login flow for Google accounts is set to
0`

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This may cause users to have to log into the OS more frequently.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Enforce local anchor constraints' Is 'Enforce constraints in locally added trust anchors'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls constraints encoded into trust anchors loaded from the platform trust store. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Do not enforce constraints in locally added trust anchors
Enabled (1): Enforce constraints in locally added trust anchors

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for EnforceLocalAnchorConstraintsEnabled
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will not allow access to any sites that do not enforce constraints.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Enforce local anchor constraints

Set Configuration
to Enforce constraints in locally added trust anchors

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this might cause certain internal sites to not properly load until they are updated.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Strict MIME type checking for worker scripts' Is Set to 'Require a JavaScript MIME type for worker scripts'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to upgrade to HTTPS from HTTP while navigating to certain sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Scripts for workers (Web Workers, Service Workers, etc.) use lax MIME type checking. Worker scripts with legacy MIME types, like text/ascii, will work.
Enabled (1): Scripts for workers (Web Workers, Service Workers, etc.) require a JavaScript MIME type, like text/javascript. Worker scripts with legacy MIME types, like text/ascii, will be rejected.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for StrictMimetypeCheckForWorkerScriptsEnabled
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will require worker scripts to use more secure and strict JavaScript MIME types and ones with legacy MIME Types will be rejected.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Strict MIME type checking for worker scripts

Set Configuration
to Require a JavaScript MIME type for worker scripts

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Certificate transparency CA allowlist' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can exclude certificates by their subjectPublicKeyInfo hashes from enforcing Certificate Transparency requirements. If this setting is disabled, no certificates are excluded from Certificate Transparency requirements.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificate Transparency requirements shall be enforced for all certificates.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Certificate transparency CA allowlist
Remove all CAs from Certificate transparency CA allowlist

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow remote debugging' is set to 'Do not allow use of the remote debugging'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting controls whether users may use remote debugging.

The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow use of the remote debugging
.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Manage Access Control for Remote Assets

notes:notes.xhtml:p: I copied/adjusted this rule from MS Edge, rule 1.41

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling remote debugging enhances security and protects applications from unauthorized access. Some attack tools can exploit this feature to extract information, or to insert malicious code.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Allow remote debugging

Set Configuration
to Do not allow use of the remote debugging

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able access the remote debugging feature in Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Certificate transparency legacy CA allowlist' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can disable the enforcing of Certificate Transparency requirements for a list of Legacy Certificate Authorities.
If this setting is disabled, certificates not properly publicly disclosed as required by Certificate Transparency are untrusted.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Legacy Certificate Authorities shall follow the Certificate Transparency policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Certificate transparency legacy CA allowlist
Remove all legacy CAs from Certificate transparency legacy CA allowlist

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'User management of installed CA certificates' Is Set to 'Disallow users from managing certificates'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy allows a user to import or remove CA certificates in Certificate Manager.

The settings for User management of installed CA certificates
are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Allow users to manage all certificates This is the default. Users can edit trust settings for all CA certificates, remove user-imported certificates, and import certificates.
Allow users to manage user certificates Users can manage only user-imported certificates, but they cant change trust settings for built-in certificates.
Disallow users from managing certificates Users can view CA certificates, but they cant manage them.

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Default Accounts on Enterprise Assets and Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Granting a user the ability to remove CA certificates could allow them to change the trust settings of built-in CA certificates. Allowing users to import their own CA certificates could allow a malicious CA certificate to be trusted.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Apps and extensions
select Users & browsers
Select User management of installed CA certificates
Set to Disallow users from managing certificates

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'User management of installed client certificates' Is Set to 'Disallow users from managing certificates'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy allows a user to import or remove certificates in Certificate Manager.

The settings for User management of installed certificates
are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Allow users to manage all certificates This is the default. Users can edit trust settings for all certificates, remove user-imported certificates, and import certificates.
Allow users to manage user certificates Users can manage only user-imported certificates, but they cant change trust settings for built-in certificates.
Disallow users from managing certificates Users can view certificates, but they cant manage them.

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Default Accounts on Enterprise Assets and Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Granting a user the ability to remove certificates could allow them to change the trust settings of built-in certificates. Allowing users to import their own certificates could allow a malicious certificate to be trusted.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Apps and extensions
select Users & browsers
Select User management of installed client certificates
Set to Disallow users from managing certificates

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Unsupported system warning' is set to 'Allow Chrome to display warnings when running on an unsupported system'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome will show a warning that appears when Google Chrome is running on a computer or operating system that is no longer supported.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Authorized Software is Currently Supported
Ensure Software is Supported by Vendor

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The user shall be informed if the used software is no longer supported.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Unsupported system warning

Set Configuration
to Allow Chrome to display warnings when running on an unsupported system

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Override insecure origin restrictions' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use a list of origins (URLs) or hostname patterns (such as "*.example.com") for which security restrictions on insecure origins will not apply and are prevented from being labeled as "Not Secure" in the omnibox.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Insecure contexts shall always be labeled as insecure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Override insecure origin restrictions
Remove all hostnames from Origin or hostname patterns to ignore insecure origins security restrictions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Remote access clients' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The policy imposes what client domain names have access to remotely connect to the ChromeOS device. If the policy is unset then any client from any domain can connect to the ChromeOS device.

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Remote Devices Utilize a VPN and are Connecting to an Enterprises AAA Infrastructure
Maintain an Inventory of Network Boundaries

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In order to stop remote access by any client on any domain, this policy should be configured to your organization's domains that need to remotely access your ChromeOS devices.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Remote Access
, select Remote access clients

Set Remote access client domain
to your organization's required domain(s)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact to the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Remote access hosts' is set with a domain defined in 'Remote access host domain'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows the configuration of a list of domains that are allowed to access the user's system. When enabled, remote systems can only connect if they are one of the specified domains listed.
Setting this to an empty list (Disabled) allows remote systems from any domain to connect to this user's system.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1) and at least one domain set

NOTE:
The list of domains is organization specific.

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote assistance connections shall be restricted.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Remote access hosts

Set Remote access host domain
to your organization's required domain

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, only systems from the specified domains can connect to the user's system.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Firewall traversal' is set to 'Disable the use of relay servers'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows the use of relay servers when clients are trying to connect to this machine and a direct connection is not available.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disable
(0): The use of relay servers by the remote access host is not allowed

Enabled
(1): The use of relay servers by the remote access host is allowed

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Relay servers shall not be used to circumvent firewall restrictions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Firewall traversal

Set Configuration
to Disable the use of relay servers

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, remote clients can not use relay servers to connect to this machine.

NOTE:
Setting this to Disabled doesn't turn remote access off, but only allows connections from the same network (not NAT traversal or relay).

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Remote support connections' is set to 'Prevent remote support connections'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This is a setting for Chrome Remote desktop. If this setting is Disabled, the remote access host service cannot be started or configured to accept incoming connections.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0): Prevent remote access connections to this machine

Enabled
(1): Allow remote access connections to this machine

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Only approved remote access systems should be used.

NOTE:
If Chrome Remote Desktop is approved and required for use, then this setting can be ignored.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Remote support connections

Set Configuration
to Prevent remote support connections

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting will disable Chrome Remote Desktop. In general, Chrome Remote Desktop is not used by most businesses, so disabling it should have no impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Show sign-out button in tray' Is Set to 'Show sign-out button in tray'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Show sign-out button in tray
policy controls whether a sign-out button is in the system tray while the screen is not locked and the session is active.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling the sign-out button in the system tray would allow a user to quickly logout of a session in a situation where there may be malicious actors trying to 'shoulder-surf' or to capture data from the user's screen.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Session settings
, select Show sign-out button in tray

Set Show sign-out button in tray
to Show sign-out button in tray

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This would have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Cross-origin authentication' is set to 'Block cross-origin authentication'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether third-party sub-content can open a HTTP Basic Auth dialog and is typically disabled.
The recommended state for this setting is: Block cross-origin authentication

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting is typically disabled to help combat phishing attempts.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Cross-origin authentication

Set Specify whether third-party sub-content on a page is allowed to pop-up an HTTP basic authentication dialog box.
to Block cross-origin authentication

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Online revocation checks' is set to 'Do not perform online OCSP/CRL checks'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can reactivate soft-fail, online revocation checks, although they may provide some benefit in most cases.
If this setting is disabled, unsecure online OCSP/CRL checks are no longer performed.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: CRLSets are primarily a means by which Chrome can quickly block certificates in emergency situations. As a secondary function they can also contain some number of non-emergency revocations. These latter revocations are obtained by crawling CRLs published by CAs.

Online (i.e. OCSP and CRL) checks are not, by default, performed by Chrome. The underlying system certificate library always performs these checks no matter what Chrome does, so enabling it here is redundant.

An attacker may block OCSP traffic and cause revocation checks to pass in order to cause usage of soft-fail behavior. Furthermore, the browser may leak what website is being accessed and who accesses it to CA servers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Online revocation checks

Set Configuration
to Do not perform online OCSP/CRL checks

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable globally scoped HTTP authentication cache' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether HTTP auth credentials may be automatically used in the context of another web site visited in Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
This setting is intended to give enterprises depending on the legacy behavior a chance to update their login procedures and will be removed in the future.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing HTTP auth credentials to be shared without the user's consent could lead to a user sharing sensitive information without their knowledge. Enabling this setting could also lead to some types of cross-site attacks that would allow users to be tracked across sites without the use of cookies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Globally scoped HTTP authentication cache

Set Configuration
to HTTP authentication credentials are scoped to top-level sites

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Supported authentication schemes' is set to 'NTLM' and 'Negotiate'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Specifies which HTTP authentication schemes are supported by Google Chrome.

Disabled
(0): Allows all supported authentication schemes.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with the value of ntlm, negotiate

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Transmittal of Username and Authentication Credentials

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Possible values are 'basic', 'digest', 'ntlm' and 'negotiate'. Basic and Digest authentication do not provide sufficient security and can lead to submission of user passwords in plaintext or minimal protection (Integrated Authentication is supported for negotiate and ntlm challenges only).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Supported authentication schemes

Set Configuration
to NTLM
and Negotiate

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If some legacy application(s) or website(s) required insecure authentication mechanisms they will not work correctly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SSL error override' is set to 'Block users from clicking through SSL warnings'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether a user is able to proceed to a webpage when an invalid SSL certificate warning has occurred.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Sites protected by SSL should always be recognized as valid in the web browser. Allowing a user to make the decision as to whether there appears to be an invalid certificate could open an organization up to users visiting a site that is otherwise not secure and/or malicious in nature.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select SSL error override

Set Configuration
to Block users from clicking through SSL warnings

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to click past the invalid certificate error to view the website.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Proxy mode' is Not Set to 'Always auto detect the proxy'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the functionality to configure the proxy settings by automatic discovery using WPAD (Web Proxy Auto-Discovery Protocol). Setting this configures the proxy settings for Chrome and ARC-apps, which ignore all proxy-related options specified from the command line.

Disabled
(0): Lets users choose their proxy settings.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
and the value of ProxyMode
is not set to auto_detect

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Application Layer Filtering Proxy Server

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Attackers may abuse the WPAD auto-config functionality to supply computers with a PAC file that specifies a rogue web proxy under their control.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Proxy mode

Set Configuration
to a setting other than Always auto detect the proxy

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If the policy is enabled, the proxy configuration will no longer be discovered using WPAD.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Ignore proxy on captive portals' Is Set to 'Keep policies for captive portal pages'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy configures the ability for Google ChromeOS to bypass any proxy for captive portal authentication.

If enabled, this causes authentication webpages starting from the captive portal sign-in page until Chrome detects a successful internet connection to open in a separate window and ignore all policy settings and restrictions for the current user.
If disabled, this means any captive portal authentication pages are shown in a new browser tab that uses the current user's proxy settings.
This policy only takes effect if a proxy is set up (by policy, extension, or the user in chrome://settings).

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Network Architecture
Maintain an Inventory of Authorized Wireless Access Points

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling captive portal sites to bypass proxy settings could grant access to the system from a malicious (or misconfigured) captive portal site. Setting the policy to disabled forces all sites, including captive portal sites, to use the configured proxy settings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Ignore proxy on captive portals
to Keep policies for captive portal pages

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This may impact a user's access to certain captive portal sites that do not work with the configured proxy server.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'WebRTC ICE candidate URLs for local IPs' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting specifies a list of URLs or patterns for which local IP addresses will be exposed by WebRTC.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
This setting, if Enabled, weakens the protection of local IPs if needed by administrators.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting and allowing exposure of IP addresses can allow an attacker to gather information about the internal network that could potentially be utilized to breach and traverse a network.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select WebRTC ICE candidate URLs for local IPs
Remove all URLs from URLs for which local IPs are exposed in WebRTC ICE candidates

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'DNS over HTTPS' is set to 'Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This controls the mode of the DNS-over-HTTPS resolver. Please note that this setting will only set the default mode for each query. The mode may be overridden for special types of queries, such as requests to resolve a DNS-over-HTTPS server hostname.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disable DNS-over-HTTPS
(off)

Enable DNS-over-HTTPS with insecure fallback
(automatic) - Enable DNS-over-HTTPS queries first if a DNS-over-HTTPS server is available and may fallback to sending insecure queries on error.

Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback
(secure) - Only send DNS-over-HTTPS queries and will fail to resolve on error.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback
(secure)

Note:
When enabling this policy, it is recommended to also configure the DnsOverHttpsTemplates
policy so that the URI templates are set. You can find out more information on the DnsOverHttpsTemplates
enterprise policy site
.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: DNS over HTTPS (DOH) has a couple primary benefits:

xhtml:li.xhtml:p: Encrypting DNS name resolution traffic helps to hide your online activities, since DoH hides the name resolution requests from the ISP and from anyone listening on intermediary networks.
DoH also helps to prevent DNS spoofing and man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select DNS over HTTPS

Set Configuration
to Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Not all DNS providers support DOH, so choice is limited. Also, Enterprises sometimes monitor DNS requests to block access to malicious or inappropriate sites. DNS monitoring can also sometimes be used to detect malware attempting to "phone home." Because DoH encrypts name resolution requests, it can create a security monitoring blind spot.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'HSTS policy bypass list' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows a list of names to be specified that will be exempt from HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) policy checks, then potentially upgraded from http:// to https://.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing hostnames to be exempt from HSTS checks could allow for protocol downgrade attacks and cookie hijackings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select HSTS policy bypass list
Remove all hostnames from List of hostnames that will bypass the HSTS policy check

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Automatic HTTPS upgrades' Is Set to 'Allow HTTPS upgrades'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to upgrade to HTTPS from HTTP while navigating to certain sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable HTTPS Upgrades
Enabled (1): HTTPS Upgrades may be applied depending on feature launch status

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for HttpsUpgradesEnabled
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting will upgrade the connection to a site from HTTP to HTTPS where available, verifying the identity of the site visited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Automatic HTTPS upgrades

Set Configuration
to Allow HTTPS upgrades

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

Note:
If there are internal sites/servers that use HTTP only, set those in the policy HttpAllowlist

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Http Allowlist' Is Properly Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This setting allows administrators to list specific sites that will not be upgraded to HTTPS and will not show an error interstitial if HTTPS-First Mode
is enabled.

Note:
Wildcards ( *
, [*]
, etc.) are not allowed in the URL listings.

controls:safeguard.title: Integrate Software and Hardware Asset Inventories

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy allows organizations to maintain access to servers that do not support HTTPS without having to disable HTTPS-First mode or HTTPS Upgrades.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select HTTP Allowlist

Set Allowed HTTP URLs
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should not have an impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'DNS interception checks enabled' is set to 'Perform DNS interception checks '

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines whether a local switch is configured for DNS interception checks. These checks attempt to discover if the browser is behind a proxy that redirects unknown host names.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

NOTE:
This detection might not be necessary in an enterprise environment where the network configuration is known. It can be disabled to avoid additional DNS and HTTP traffic on startup and each DNS configuration change.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Unsuccessful Administrative Account Login

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling these checks could potentially allow DNS hijacking and poisoning.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select DNS interception checks enabled

Set Configuration
to Perform DNS interception checks

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Cast' is set to 'Do not allow users to cast'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This setting controls whether Google Cast is able to connect to all IP Addresses or only private IP Addresses as defined in RFC1918 (IPv4) and RFC4193 (IPv6). Note that if the EnabledMediaRouter
setting is set to Disabled
there is no positive or negative effect for this setting.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing Google Cast to connect to public IP addresses could allow media and other potentially sensitive data to be exposed to the public. Disabling this setting will ensure that Google Cast is only able to connect to private (ie: internal) IP addresses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Cast

Set Allow users to Cast from Chrome
to Do not allow users to cast

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Cast' is set to 'Do not allow users to Cast'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Cast can send the contents of tabs, sites, or the desktop from the browser to a remote display and sound system.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Cast may send the contents of tabs, sites, or the desktop from the browser to non-trusted devices on the local network segment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Cast

Set Configuration
to Do not allow users to Cast

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this is disabled, Google Cast is not activated and the toolbar icon is not shown.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow third-party partitioning to be enabled' in 'Third-party storage partitioning' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting will block specific sites your organization selects from accessing the storage session from any other site. This will allow an organization to block third party trackers that are embedded on multiple sites from tracking a user across the sites they visit. It will also allow blocking third party access to the user agent and to infer data about the user from the data from another site.

Setting the Level 2 recommendation Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled
will remove any sites listed in Allow third-party partitioning to be enabled
and block all sites.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If your organization does not want to block all third-party sites from accessing the user agent, you can configure a curated list of sites to block.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Third-party storage partitioning

Set Third-party storage partitioning
to to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This might cause the user experience to vary from allowed sites to blocked sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Third-party storage partitioning' Is Set to 'Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting will block any site from accessing the storage session from any other site. This will block third party trackers that are embedded on multiple sites from tracking a user across the sites they visit. Blocking third party access to the user agent will not allow sites to infer data about the user from the data from another site.
It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Enabled (1): Allow third-party storage partitioning to be enabled.
Disabled (2): Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce Members on Recognizing and Reporting Security Incidents

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this requires that user agent state needs to be keyed by more than a single origin or site. It can also defend against timing attacks on web privacy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Third-party storage partitioning

Set Configuration
to Block third-party storage partitioning from being enabled

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enforcing this may cause users to experience issues with sites they regularly visit that already grant access to third-parties.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Control use of insecure content exceptions' is set to 'Do not allow any site to load mixed content'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Setting controls whether users can add exceptions to allow mixed content for specific sites.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to load mixed content
(2)

Allow users to add exceptions to allow mixed content
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with the value of Do not allow any site to load mixed content
(2)

NOTE:
This policy can be overridden for specific URL patterns using the InsecureContentAllowedForUrls
and InsecureContentBlockedForUrls
policies.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing mixed (secure / insecure) content from a site can lead to malicious content being loaded. Mixed content occurs if the initial request is secure over HTTPS, but HTTPS and HTTP content is subsequently loaded to display the web page. HTTPS content is secure. HTTP content is insecure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Control use of insecure content exceptions

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to load mixed content

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to mix content.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection' is set to 'Data collection is never active'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the feature URL-keyed anonymized data collection. This sends URLs of pages the user visits to Google to optimize its services.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymized data collection shall be disabled, since it is unclear which information exactly is sent to Google.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection

Set Configuration
to Data collection is never active

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Anonymized data will not be sent to Google to help optimize its services

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Web Bluetooth API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has an API which allows the access to nearby Bluetooth devices from the browser with users consent.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API
(2)

Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a nearby Bluetooth device
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Disable Wireless Peripheral Access of Devices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A malicious website could exploit a vulnerable Bluetooth device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Web Bluetooth API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is configured, websites can no longer access nearby Bluetooth devices via the API (this includes web cameras, headphones, and other Bluetooth devices) and the user will never be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow local file access to file:// URLs on these sites in the PDF Viewer' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This setting will allow specified URLs to access file://
URLs in the PDF Viewer. By default all domains are blocked from accessing file://
URLs in the PDF Viewer

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce Members on Recognizing and Reporting Security Incidents

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Blocking all domains, or a restricted list of domains, from opening a downloaded PDF file blocks the possibility of a malicious file being masked as a PDF. It could also block unknown or malicious code contained within the PDF that would run on the immediate opening within a browser tab.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Allow local file access to file:// URLs on these sites in the PDF Viewer
Remove all URLs from Allowed URLs

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be required to open PDF files manually in the PDF Viewer or in the organization's PDF viewing application.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Cookies' is set to 'Session Only'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When leaving the setting _RestoreOnStartup _unset results in the use of _DefaultCookiesSetting _for all sites, if it's set. If _DefaultCookiesSetting _is not set, the user's personal setting applies.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0, user's personal setting applies)

Allow all sites to set local data
(1)

Do not allow any site to set local data
(2)

Keep cookies for the duration of the session
(4)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Keep cookies for the duration of the session
(4)

NOTE:
If the RestoreOnStartup
setting is set to restore URLs from previous sessions this setting will not be respected and cookies will be stored permanently for those sites. An example of those URLs are SSO or intranet sites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Permanently stored cookies may be used for malicious intent.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Cookies

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, cookies will be cleared when the session closes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'First-Party Sets' Is Set to 'Disable First-Party Sets for all affected users'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls access to the First-Party Sets. First-Party Sets are a way for sites to declare relationships with each other and enable limited cross-site cookie access for specific, user-facing purposes. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Disable First-Party Sets for all affected users
Enabled (1): Enable First-Party Sets for all affected users

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will not allow sites to declare the relationships that allow them to access the cross-site cookies.
