xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select First-Party Sets

Set Configuration
to Disable First-Party Sets for all affected users

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This may cause unexpected behavior as a user moves between affiliated sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Third-party cookie blocking' is set to 'Disallow third-party cookies'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows cookies to be set by web page elements that are not from the domain in the user's address bar. Enabling this feature prevents third party cookies from being set.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Blocking third-party cookies can help protect a user's privacy by eliminating a number of website tracking cookies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Third-party cookie blocking

Set Configuration
to Disallow third-party cookies

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents cookies from being set by web page elements that are not from the domain that is in the browser's address bar.

NOTE
: Third Party Cookies and Tracking Protection are required for many business critical websites, including Microsoft 365 web apps (Office 365), SalesForce, and SAP Analytics Cloud. If these, or similar services, are needed by the organization, then this setting can be Disabled.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Screen video capture' is set to 'Do not allow sites to prompt the user to share a video stream of their screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If enabled or not configured (default), a Web page can use screen-share APIs (e.g., getDisplayMedia() or the Desktop Capture extension API) to prompt the user to select a tab, window, or desktop to capture.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny screen capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing screen capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Screen video capture

Set Configuration
to Do not allow sites to prompt the user to share a video stream of their screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

When this policy is disabled, any calls to screen-share APIs will fail with an error. This policy is not considered (and a site will be allowed to use screen-share APIs) if the site matches an origin pattern in any of the following policies: ScreenCaptureAllowedByOrigins, WindowCaptureAllowedByOrigins, TabCaptureAllowedByOrigins, SameOriginTabCaptureAllowedByOrigins.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Notifications' is set to 'Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers websites the ability to display desktop notifications. These are push messages which are sent from the website operator through Google infrastructure to Chrome.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Allow sites to show desktop notifications
(1)

Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications
(2)

Ask every time a site wants to show desktop notifications
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications
(2)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the website operator decides to send messages unencrypted, Google's servers may process it as plain text. Furthermore, potentially compromised or faked notifications might trick users into clicking on a malicious link.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Notifications

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled and set to Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications
, notifications will not be displayed for any sites and the user will not be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Clipboard' Is Set to 'Do not allow any site to use the clipboard site permission'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for clipboard permission access from sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (2): Does not allow access to the clipboard site permission by any site
Enabled (3): Sites ask the user to allow access to the clipboard site permission

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for DefaultClipboardSetting
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled. ClipboardAllowedForUrls
or ClipboardBlockedForUrls
will override this setting for any site that matches the configured URL patterns.

With the setting disabled, organizations will need to set ClipboardAllowedForUrls
for any URLs they want to make exempt.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

notes:notes.xhtml:p: If your organization requires a set of sites permitted to access the clipboard, configure them via this setting in the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User &amp; browser settings
, select Clipboard
Set URLs required by your organization in Allow these sites to access the clipboard

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The clipboard stores data, text, and images that are shared between all applications. An organization would disable clipboard access to restrict sites from reading the contents of the clipboard when visiting.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Clipboard

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to use the clipboard site permission

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Not allowing sites to have access to the clipboard permission can cause issues with formatting or access to needed images on the clipboard.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SafeSearch and Restricted Mode' is set to 'Always use Safe Search for Google Web Search queries'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting ensures that web search results with Google are performed with SafeSearch set to always active. Disabled means SafeSearch in Google Search is not enforced.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content, including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select SafeSearch and Restricted Mode

Set Configuration
to Always use Safe Search for Google Web Search queries

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos, and images will not be shown.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Screen video capture' is set to 'Do not allow sites to prompt the user to share a video stream of their screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether Google Chrome can use screen-share APIs, including web-based online meetings, video, or screen sharing.

The recommended state for this setting is Do not allow sites to prompt the user to share a video stream of their screen
.

NOTE:
This setting is not considered (and a site will be allowed to use screen-share APIs) if the site matches an origin pattern in any of the following other settings: ScreenCaptureAllowedByOrigins
, WindowCaptureAllowedByOrigins
, TabCaptureAllowedByOrigins
, SameOriginTabCaptureAllowedByOrigins
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing screen-share APIs within Google Chrome could potentially allow for sensitive data to be shared via screen captures.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Screen video capture

Set Configuration
to Do not allow sites to prompt the user to share a video stream of their screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Users will be unable to utilize APIs which support web-based meetings (video conferencing screen sharing), video, and screen capture. This could potentially cause disruption to users who may have utilized these abilities in the past.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Auto open downloaded files' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether specified file types are allowed to auto open on download. It also controls specified URLs to allow those specified file types to auto open when they are downloaded from those URLs.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Devices Not To Auto-run Content

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: No file types should not be allowed to auto open and the user is required to interact with every downloaded file they wish to open.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Content
, select Auto open downloaded files
Remove all file types from Auto open file types
Remove all URLs from Auto open URLs

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There is no impact to the user

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Download location prompt' is set to 'Ask the user where to save the file before downloading'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to download files automatically to the default download directory without prompting.
If this setting is enabled, users are always asked where to save each file before downloading.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from the drive-by-downloads threat.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Download location prompt

Set Configuration
to Ask the user where to save the file before downloading

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'File selection dialogs' is set to 'Block file selection dialogs'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows access to local files by allowing file selection dialogs in Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Integrate Software and Hardware Asset Inventories

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing users to import favorites, upload files, and save links could pose potential security risks by allowing data to be uploaded to external sites or by downloading malicious files. By not allowing the file selection dialog, the end-user will not be prompted for uploads/downloads, preventing data exfiltration and possible system infection by malware.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select File selection dialogs

Set Configuration
to Block file selection dialogs

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will no longer be prompted when performing actions which would trigger a file selection dialog. Instead, the file selection dialog box assumes the user clicked "Cancel". Being as this is not the default behavior, impact to the user will be noticeable, and the user will not be able to upload and download files.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Prohibited Native Messaging hosts' in 'Native Messaging blocked hosts' is set to '*'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to specify which native messaging hosts should not be loaded.

Disabled
(0): Google Chrome will load all installed native messaging hosts.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of *

NOTE:
This needs to be handled carefully. If an extension is enabled, yet can't communicate with its backend code, it could behave in strange ways which results in helpdesk tickets + support load.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For consistency with Plugin and Extension policies, native messaging should be blocklisted by default, requiring explicit administrative approval of applications for allowlisting. An example of an application that uses native messaging is the 1Password password manager.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Native Messaging blocked hosts

Set Prohibited Native Messaging hosts
to *

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
A blocklist value of '*' means all native messaging hosts are blocklisted unless they are explicitly listed in the allowlist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Browser guest mode' is set to 'Prevent guest browser logins'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether a user may utilize guest profiles in Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In a guest profile, the browser doesn't import browsing data from existing profiles, and it deletes browsing data when all guest profiles are closed.

Deleting browser data will delete information that may be important for a computer investigation, and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Browser guest mode

Set Configuration
to Prevent guest browser logins

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to initiate Guest mode for Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Payment methods' is set to 'Always tell websites that no payment methods are saved'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows you to set whether a website can check to see if the user has payment methods saved.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Saving payment information in Google Chrome could lead to sensitive data being leaked and used for non-legitimate purposes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Payment methods

Set Configuration
to Always tell websites that no payment methods are saved

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Websites will be unable to query whether payment information within Google Chrome is available.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow user feedback' is set to 'Do not allow user feedback'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether users are able to utilize the Chrome feedback feature to send feedback, suggestions, and surveys to Google, as well as issue reports.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Data should not be shared with third-party vendors in an enterprise managed environment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Allow user feedback

Set Configuration
to Do not allow user feedback

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to send feedback to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Google Translate' is set to 'Never offer translation'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google translation services on Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Content of internal web pages may be leaked to Google's translation service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Google Translate

Set Configuration
to Never offer translation

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After disabling this feature, the contents of a web page are no longer sent to Google for translation.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Network prediction' Is Set to 'Do not predict network actions'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome comes with the network prediction feature which provides DNS prefetching, TCP and SSL preconnection, and prerendering of web pages.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Predict network actions on any network connection
(0) or (1)

Do not predict network actions on any network connection
(2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not predict network actions on any network connection
(2)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Opening connections to resources that may not be used could allow unneeded connections, increasing the attack surface, and in some cases could lead to opening connections to resources which the user did not intend to utilize.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Network prediction

Set Configuration
to Do not predict network actions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be presented with web page predictions.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Spell check service' is set to 'Disable the spell checking web service'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use Google web service to help resolve spelling errors.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information typed in may be leaked to Google's spellcheck web service.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Spell check service

Set Configuration
to Disable the spell checking web service

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

After disabling this feature, Chrome no longer sends the entire contents of text fields to Google as you type them. Spell checking can still be performed using a downloaded dictionary. This setting only controls the usage of the online service.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Alternate error pages' is set to 'Never use alternate error pages'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to show suggestions for the page you were trying to reach when it is unable to connect to a web address such as 'Page Not Found'.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Using navigation suggestions may leak information about the web site intended to be visited.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Alternate error pages

Set Configuration
to Never use alternate error pages

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, Chrome will no longer use a web service to help resolve navigation errors.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Address form Autofill' is set to 'Never Autofill address forms'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved information such as address or phone number. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored address AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Address form Autofill

Set Configuration
to Never Autofill address forms

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Credit card form Autofill' is set to 'Never Autofill credit card forms'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved credit card information. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored credit card AutoFill data, information could be harvested.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Credit card form Autofill

Set Configuration
to Never Autofill credit card forms

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, credit card AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Connected devices
sub-section deals with the interaction between Android devices with computers running the Chrome browser or running ChromeOS. With the requirement of additional devices, we are not giving any guidance on using Connected devices
. We are recommending your organization goes through this section and makes determinations on how these should be configured.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enterprise Hardware Platform API' is set to 'Do not allow managed extensions to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows extensions installed by enterprise policies to be allowed to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: It is recommended that this setting is disabled unless otherwise directed by Enterprise policies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Enterprise Hardware Platform API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow managed extensions to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has an API which allows access to connected USB devices from the browser

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API
(2)

Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a connected USB device
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: WebUSB is opening the doors for sophisticated phishing attacks that could bypass hardware-based two-factor authentication devices (e.g. Yubikey devices).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select WebUSB API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is configured, websites can no longer access connected USB devices via the API (this includes web cameras, headphones, and other USB devices) which could also prevent some two factor authentication (2FA) USB devices from working properly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Privacy screen' Is Set to 'Always enable the privacy screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The privacy screen for ChromeOS is a feature that activates when the user walks away from the Chromebook. If activated, the screen will dim after 10 seconds. It can also keep the screen awake while the user is in front of the Chromebook even if they are not interacting with the device.
This policy requires a built in webcam and for ChromeOS devices with an integrated electronic privacy screen.

controls:safeguard.title: Enforce Automatic Device Lockout on Portable End-User Devices
Maintain an Inventory of Authentication Systems

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting the operating system to automatically dim and lock the screen when the user moves away from the device protects potentially sensitive data that may reside on their machine.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Privacy screen
to Always enable the privacy screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Sensors' is set to 'Do not allow any site to access sensors'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of system sensors such as motion and light.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Allow sites to access sensors
(1)

Do not allow any site to access sensors
(2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to access sensors
(2)

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Do not allow any site to access sensors

NOTE:
If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SensorsAllowedForUrls
and SensorsBlockedForUrls
settings. For example, SensorsAllowedForUrls
can be used to allow sensor access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system sensors may prevent malicious sites from using these sensors for user profiling (OpSec).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Sensors

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to access sensors

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Web Serial API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Web Serial API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of the system serial port.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API
(2)

Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a serial port
(3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API
(2)

NOTE:
If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls
, SerialAskForUrls
and SerialBlockedForUrls
settings. For example, SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls
can be used to allow serial port access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system serial ports may prevent malicious sites from using these ports and accessing the devices attached.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Web Serial API

Set Configuration
to Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Web Serial API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Video input (camera)' is set to 'Disable camera input for websites and apps'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to video capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0): Turns off prompts and video capture will only work for URLs configured in the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls
list.

Enabled
(1): With the exception of URLs set in the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls
list, users get prompted for video capture access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
NOTE:
The setting affects all video input (not just the built-in camera).

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny video capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing video capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Video input (camera)

Set Configuration
to Disable camera input for websites and apps

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for video devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites to which access will be allowed, configuration of the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls
setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Audio input (microphone)' is set to 'Disable audio input'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to audio capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0): Turns off prompts and audio capture will only work for URLs configured in the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls
list.

Enabled
(1): With the exception of URLs set in the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls
list, users get prompted for audio capture access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
NOTE:
The setting affects all audio input (not just the built-in microphone).
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny audio capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing audio capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Audio input (microphone)

Set Configuration
to Disable audio input

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for audio devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites to which access will be allowed, configuration of the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls
setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Verified Mode' Is Set to 'Require verified mode boot for Verified Access'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Verified Access ensures that a device connecting to your network has been unmodified and is policy- compliant. Verified Access serves as an access point for a network service (such as a VPN gateway, a sensitive server, an enterprise Certificate Authority [CA], or an enterprise Wi-Fi access point) to get a hardware-backed cryptographic guarantee of the identity of the device and user thats trying to access it.

Verified Access uses the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) - present in every Chrome OS device - to enable enterprise network services to cryptographically confirm the identity and status of secure mode and enterprise policy using a Google server-side Application Programming Interface (API).

controls:safeguard.title: Enable Operating System Anti-Exploitation Features/ Deploy Anti-Exploit Technologies

notes:notes.xhtml:p: To properly configure Verified Mode, your organization will need to create both a Chrome extension and a network service endpoint. To set up both the extension and the network service endpoint, follow the instructions in the Chrome Verified Access Developer's Guide

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Chrome Verified Access API allows network services, such as VPNs, intranet pages, and so on to cryptographically verify that their clients are genuine and conform to corporate policy. Most large enterprises have the requirement to allow only enterprise-managed devices onto their WPA2 EAP-TLS networks, higher-tier access in VPNs, and mutual-TLS intranet pages.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User verification
, select Verified Mode

Set Verified Mode boot check
to Verified Mode

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This would impact a user that is required to use a development branch of ChromeOS.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Managed browser reporting' Is Set to 'Enable managed browser cloud reporting'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls the upload of information from the operation of the browser to your organization's Google Admin console.
By default, this policy is disabled and there is no data collected. When enabled, the data is collected and uploaded to the Google Admin console.

Note:
For Chrome browser, this policy requires your organization to use Chrome Browser Cloud Management (CBCM). CBCM is not required for ChromeOS.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling logging will give your organization a detailed view of ChromeOS, the Chrome browser, and the extensions in use.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Browser reporting
, select Managed browser reporting

Set Browser reporting
to Enable managed browser cloud reporting

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Managed browser reporting upload frequency' Is Set to Less Than or Equal to 24 Hours

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This policy controls the frequency of uploads of the Chrome status reports to your organization's Google Admin console. This policy includes the reports when setting Managed browser reporting
to Enable managed browser cloud reporting
.
When unset, this policy defaults to uploading status reports every 24 hours. If set to another time amount, the policy will upload successive status reports as defined by the policy.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The frequency of uploads should match your organization's requirements but should not exceed 24 hours. This allows faster response to any anomalies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Browser reporting
, select Managed browser reporting upload frequency

Set Managed browser reporting upload frequency
to 24

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure no URLs Are Configured in 'Safe Browsing allowed domains'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The setting determines the functionality of Safe Browsing.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0): Safe Browsing protection applies to all resources

Enabled
(1), with a list of 1 or more sites: Means Safe Browsing will trust the domains you designate. It won't check them for dangerous resources such as phishing, malware, or unwanted software.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
Safe Browsing's download protection service won't check downloads hosted on these domains, and its password protection service won't check for password reuse.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Safe Browsing will help protect users from a variety of malicious and fraudulent sites, or from downloading dangerous files.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Safe Browsing allowed domains
Remove any URLs from Allowed Domains

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

NOTE:
The only real impact is possible user annoyance if they are going to a legitimate site that is falsely considered fraudulent (a rare occurrence). This can be handled by adding the site to the allowlist and/or notifying Google of the false finding.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Download restrictions' is set to 'Block malicious downloads'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can block certain types of downloads, and won't let users bypass the security warnings, depending on the classification of Safe Browsing.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Block malicious downloads and dangerous file types.
(1)

Block malicious downloads, uncommon or unwanted downloads, and dangerous file types.
(2)

Block all downloads.
(3)

Block malicious downloads. Recommended.
(4)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Block malicious downloads. Recommended.
(4)

NOTE:
These restrictions apply to downloads triggered from webpage content, as well as the "Download link..." menu option. They don't apply to the download of the currently displayed page or to saving as PDF from the printing options.

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Backups Have At least One Non-Continuously Addressable Destination

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from downloading malicious file types and shall not be able to bypass security warnings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Download restrictions

Set Configuration
to Block malicious downloads

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled, all downloads are allowed, except for those that carry Safe Browsing warnings. These are downloads that have been identified as risky or from a risky source by the Google Safe Browsing Global intelligence engine
.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Safe Browsing protection' is set to 'Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode' and 'Allow higher-protection proxied lookups'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether Google Chrome's Safe Browsing feature is enabled and the mode in which it operates. If you set this setting as mandatory, users cannot change or override the Safe Browsing setting in Google Chrome.
If this setting is left unset, Safe Browsing will operate in Standard Protection mode. Users, however, can change this setting.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
No Protection
(0): Safe Browsing is never active.

Standard Protection
(1): Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode.

Enhanced Protection
(2): Safe Browsing is active in the enhanced mode. This mode provides better security, but requires sharing more browsing information with Google.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode.
(1) or higher

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Safe Browsing will help protect users from a variety of malicious and fraudulent sites, or from downloading dangerous files.
For more details, please refer to the items in the References section below.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Safe Browsing protection

Ensure Safe Browsing Protection Level
is set to Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode

Ensure Allow Safe Browsing's standard protection mode to send partial hashes of URLs to Google
is set to Allow higher-protection proxied lookups

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior (Standard Protection).

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SafeSites URL filter' is set to 'Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use the Google Safe Search API to classify URLs as pornographic or not.
The recommended state for this setting is: Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select SafeSites URL filter

Set Configuration
to Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users' search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos, and images will not be shown.

NOTE:
Using Googles Safe Search API may leak information which is typed/pasted by mistake into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable bypassing Safe Browsing warnings' is set to 'Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google provides the Safe Browsing service. It shows a warning page when users navigate to sites that are flagged as potentially malicious.

Disabled
(0): Users can choose to proceed to the flagged site after the warning appears.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious web pages are widely spread on the internet and pose the most significant threat to the user today. Users shall be prevented from navigating to potentially malicious web content.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Disable bypassing Safe Browsing warnings

Set Configuration
to Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents users from proceeding anyway from the warning page to the malicious site. In some cases legitimate sites could be blocked and users would be prevented from accessing.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Safe Browsing for trusted sources' is set to 'Perform Safe Browsing checks on all downloaded files'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can be adjusted to allow downloads without Safe Browsing checks when the requested file is from a trusted source. Trusted sources can be defined using recommendation 'Configure the list of domains on which Safe Browsing will not trigger warnings'.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

NOTE:
On Microsoft Windows, this functionality is only available on instances that are joined to a Microsoft Active Directory domain, running on Windows 10 Pro, or enrolled in Chrome Browser Cloud Management.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Information requested from trusted sources shall not be sent to Google's safe browsing servers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Safe Browsing for trusted sources

Set Configuration
to Perform Safe Browsing checks on all downloaded files

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, files downloaded from intranet resources will not be checked by Google Services.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting prevents the display of lookalike URL warnings on the sites listed. These warnings are typically shown on sites that Google Chrome believes might be trying to spoof another site with which the user is familiar.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disabled
(0) or set to an empty list: Warnings may appear on any site the user visits.

Enabled
(1) and set to one or more domains: No lookalike warnings pages will be shown when the user visits pages on that domain.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Look-alike domains are intentionally misleading to give users the false impression that theyre interacting with trusted brands, leading to significant reputation damage, financial losses, and data compromise for established enterprises.

In addition, this technique is commonly used to host phishing sites, and often leads to account takeover attacks. Users are prompted to enter their credentials on a fake website, and scammers take control of their online accounts with little effort to engage in fraudulent activity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains
Remove all URLs from Allowlisted Domains

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

NOTE:
The only real impact is possible user annoyance if they are going to a legitimate site that is falsely considered fraudulent (a rare occurrence). This can be handled by adding the site to the allowlist and/or notifying Google of the false finding.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Component updates' is set to 'Enable updates for all components'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome's Component Updater updates several components of Google Chrome on a regular basis (applies only to Chrome browser components).

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

NOTE:
Updates to any component that does not contain executable code, does not significantly alter the behavior of the browser, or is critical for its security will not be disabled (E.g. certificate revocation lists and Safe Browsing data is updated regardless of this setting). FYI chrome://components
lists all components, but not if they are affected by this setting.

NOTE:
Google provided the following list of some of the components
controlled by this setting:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Recovery component
Pnacl
Floc
Optimization hints
SSL error assistant
CRL set
Origin trials
SW reporter
PKI metadata

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
To check the current components versions, navigate to chrome://components
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Chrome Updater shall be used to keep the components bundled to Chrome up to date.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Component updates

Set Configuration
to Enable updates for all components

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Relaunch notification' sets 'Time Period (hours)' to '168 or less' and 'Initial quiet period (hours)' to less than 'Time Period (hours)'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows administrators to set the time period, in milliseconds, over which users are notified that it must be relaunched to apply a pending update.

If not set, or Disabled
, the default period of 604800000 milliseconds (7 days) is used.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with value 86400000
(1 day)

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting is a notification for the end-user informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization, it is pertinent that said update takes effect as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure users restart the browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Relaunch notification

Set Time Period (hours)
to a value 168

Set Initial quiet period (hours)
to a value <
the value of Time Period (hours)

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After this time period, the user will be repeatedly informed of the need for an update until a Browser restart is completed.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Relaunch notification' is set to 'Show notification recommending relaunch'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can notify users that it must be restarted to apply a pending update. This setting controls how users are notified to relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device to get the latest update.
The control can be set to one of three options:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: No relaunch notification: Activates a minimal default level of notifications. Chrome browser indicates to users that a relaunch is needed via subtle changes to its menu. In ChromeOS, a notification in the system tray prompts the user to relaunch.

Show notification recommending relaunch: Users see a recurring message that they should relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device. Users can close the notification and keep using the old version of Chrome browser or ChromeOS until they choose to relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device.

Force relaunch after a period: Users can close the notification but will see a recurring message that they need to relaunch Chrome browser or restart their ChromeOS device within a certain amount of time.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is required
(2)

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user will receive a notification informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization it is pertinent that the update is applied as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure that users restart their browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Relaunch notification

Set Configuration
to Show notification recommending relaunch

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A recurring warning will be shown to the user indicating that a browser relaunch will be forced once the notification period passes. The user's session is restored after the relaunch of Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Variations' is set to 'Enable Chrome variations'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Configuring this setting allows specifying which variations are allowed to be applied in Google Chrome. Variations provide a means for Google to offer modifications to Google Chrome without shipping a new version of the browser by selectively enabling or disabling already existing features.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Enable all variations
: Allows all variations to be applied to the browser (Default value).

Enable variations concerning critical fixes only
: Allows only variations considered critical security or stability fixes to be applied to Google Chrome.

Disable all variations
: Prevent all variations from being applied to the browser. Please note that this mode can potentially prevent the Google Chrome developers from providing critical security fixes in a timely manner and is thus not recommended.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enable all variations
(0)

NOTE:
Google strongly believes there is no added security benefit for turning this to critical fixes, as leaving it on increases the stability of the browser. Disabling variations can also prevent getting critical security updates in a timely manner.

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google strongly recommends leaving this setting at the default (0 = Enable all variations), so fixes are gradually enabled (or if necessary, rapidly disabled) via the Chrome Variations framework.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Variations

Set Configuration
to Enable Chrome variations

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow reporting of domain reliability related data' Is 'Never send domain reliability data to Google'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for clipboard permission access from sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Never send domain reliability data to Google
Enabled (1): Domain Reliability data may be sent to Google depending on Chrome User Metrics (UMA) policy

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for DomainReliabilityAllowed
is not changed from the default, it will behave as it is enabled.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy to disabled can stop any accidental data leakage.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Allow reporting of domain reliability related data

Set Configuration
to Never send domain reliability data to Google

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Chrome Sync (ChromeOS)' is set to 'Allow Chrome Sync' and Exclude 'Passwords'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows you to specify data types that will be limited/excluded from uploading data to the Google Chrome synchronization service.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with the following text value passwords
(Case Sensitive)

NOTE:
Other settings in addition to passwords
can be included based on organizational needs.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Storing and sharing information could potentially expose sensitive information, including but not limited to user passwords and login information. Allowing this synchronization could also potentially allow an end user to pull corporate data that was synchronized into the cloud to a personal machine.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Chrome Sync (ChromeOS)

Set Configuration
to Allow Chrome Sync

Set List of types that should be excluded from synchronization
to Passwords

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Password data will not be synchronized with the Google Chrome synchronization service.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Device
section is where ChromeOS only configurations exist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Forced re-enrollment' Is Set to 'Force device to re-enroll with user credentials after wiping'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy can force your organization's ChromeOS devices to re-enroll to your account after a device wipe. By default, a user is not required to enter a username and password for re-enrollment to occur. Re-enrollment ensures that your organization's ChromeOS devices remain managed, and that the policies you set are enforced on the device.
The three settings for this policy are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Force device to automatically re-enroll after wiping ChromeOS devices automatically re-enroll into your organization's account after a wipe without user credentials being required.
Force device to re-enroll with user credentials after wiping A User must manually re-enroll ChromeOS devices into your account by logging in with their credentials.
Device is not forced to re-enroll after wiping The ChromeOS device is not re-enrolled into yout organization's account and can be used without restrictions.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Requiring all devices to automatically re-enroll after a device wipe will keep your organization's ChromeOS devices managed. It is recommended to require user credentials to re-enroll the device. This requires a user within your organization to manually enter their credentials.

Note:
ChromeOS devices that are being used in developer mode should not be forced to re-enroll. Creating an organization in the Google admin console for just those users will allow you to turn off forced re-enrollment.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Enrollment and access
, select Forced re-enrollment

Set Forced re-enrollment
to Force device to re-enroll with user credentials after wiping

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Powerwash' Is Set to 'Allow powerwash to be triggered'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Powerwash allows a user to restore ChromeOS device to a factory state.
Allowing users to initiate a powerwash is the default.

controls:safeguard.title: Enforce Remote Wipe Capability on Portable End-User Devices
Remove Sensitive Data or Systems Not Regularly Accessed by Organization

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing a user to restore the ChromeOS device can remove any possibly malicious software that has been installed. Pairing this with forced re-enrollment allows the user to immediately re-enroll the device to your organization's account, after entering their credentials, so that it is properly managed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Enrollment and access
, select Powerwash

Set Powerwash
to Allow powerwash to be triggered

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Verified access' Is Set to 'Enable for content protection'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Verified Access ensures that a device connecting to your network has been unmodified and is policy- compliant. Verified Access serves as an access point for a network service (such as a VPN gateway, a sensitive server, an enterprise Certificate Authority [CA], or an enterprise Wi-Fi access point) to get a hardware-backed cryptographic guarantee of the identity of the device and user thats trying to access it.

Verified Access uses the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) - present in every Chrome OS device - to enable enterprise network services to cryptographically confirm the identity and status of secure mode and enterprise policy using a Google server-side Application Programming Interface (API).

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Remote Devices Utilize a VPN and are Connecting to an Enterprises AAA Infrastructure
Enable Operating System Anti-Exploitation Features/ Deploy Anti-Exploit Technologies

notes:notes.xhtml:p:
To properly configure Verified Mode, your organization will need to create both a Chrome extension and a network service endpoint. To set up both the extension and the network service endpoint, follow the instructions in the Chrome Verified Access Developer's Guide
.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Chrome Verified Access API allows network services, such as VPNs, intranet pages, and so on to cryptographically verify that their clients are genuine and conform to corporate policy. Most large enterprises have the requirement to allow only enterprise-managed devices onto their WPA2 EAP-TLS networks, higher-tier access in VPNs, and mutual-TLS intranet pages.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Enrollment and access
, select Verified access

Set Verified access
to Enable for content protection

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This would impact a user that is required to use a development branch of ChromeOS.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Disabled device return instructions' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls what text is displayed on a ChromeOS device that has been disabled due to loss or theft.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Instructions need to be created for how a disabled device is returned to your organization. A return address and contact phone number should be included in these instructions. This will alert anyone who sees the ChromeOS devices display that it needs to be returned.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Enrollment and access
, select Disabled device return instructions

Configure Disabled device return instructions
to your organization's return instructions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Guest mode' Is Set to 'Disable guest mode'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
A guest login on ChromeOS is an anonymous user session where a password is not required. The Guest mode
control allows an option to sign in as a guest on managed ChromeOS devices. When set to Allow guest mode
, then the login screen will offer the ability to sign in as a guest user. When set to Disable guest mode
, that option is removed from the login screen.

The default is Disable guest mode
for K-12 EDU domains, and Allow guest mode
on all others.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Removing the guest login option will not allow anonymous user sessions and will require each user to log in with their credentials.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Sign-in settings
, select Guest mode

Set Guest mode
to Disable guest mode

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Sign-in restriction' Is Set to 'Restrict sign-in to a list of users' and Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy creates restrictions on who is allowed to sign into your organization's ChromeOS devices. If the policy is not configured, there is no restriction on who can sign into the device(s).

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Data Inventory
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A list of users should be defined that are allowed to log into your organization's ChromeOS devices.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Sign-in settings
, select Sign-in restriction

Set Sign-in restriction
to Restrict sign-in to a list of users

Set Allowed users
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should not impact the users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Sign-in screen' Is Set to 'Never show user names and photos'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy configures whether the sign-in screen on your organization's ChromeOS devices display names and pictures of users who have signed in previously.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: All users are required to sign into the ChromeOS device with their credentials, and names and pictures should not be displayed. This prevents anyone who accesses the device to know who is either with your organization or who has signed in previously on the device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Sign-in settings
, select Sign-in screen

Set Sign-in screen
to Never show user names and photos

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This may make logging into the ChromeOS device more difficult for certain users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'User data' Is Set to 'Do not erase local user data'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether ChromeOS devices are switched to ephemeral mode. In ephemeral mode, local user data is saved on disk for the length of the session and then the data is deleted after the session is over. No data is therefore saved to the device.
The recommended state for this setting is: Do not erase local user data

Note:
When set to Do not erase local user data
, all local user data is encrypted on device.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing use of ephemeral profiles allows a user to use Google ChromeOS with no data being logged to the system. Deleting local user data will delete information that may be important for a computer investigation, and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Sign-in settings
, select User data

Set User data
to Do not erase local user data

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Privacy screen on sign-in screen' Is Set to 'Always enable the privacy screen on sign-in screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The privacy screen for ChromeOS is a feature that activates when the user walks away from the Chromebook. If activated, the screen will dim after 10 seconds. It can also keep the screen awake while the user is in front of the Chromebook even if they are not interacting with the device.
This policy requires ChromeOS devices with both a built-in webcam and an integrated electronic privacy screen.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting the operating system to automatically dim and lock the screen when the user moves away from the device protects potentially sensitive user data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Sign-in settings
, select Privacy screen on sign-in screen

Set Privacy screen on sign-in screen
to Always enable the privacy screen on sign-in screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Show numeric keyboard for password' Is Set to 'Default to a standard keyboard for password input'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether ChromeOS displays a numeric keyboard or a standard keyboard on the login screen. The two configuration options are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Default to a numeric keyboard for password input
Default to a standard keyboard for password input

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users are not allowed to use a strictly numeric password to sign in, therefore the policy should require a standard keyboard. This is the default behavior.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Sign-in settings
, select Show numeric keyboard for password

Set Show numeric keyboard for password
to Default to a standard keyboard for password input

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: ChromeOS devices should be properly configured to update automatically.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow devices to automatically update OS version' Is Set to 'Allow updates'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls the automatic updating of ChromeOS.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Operating System Patch Management
Deploy Automated Operating System Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Automatic updates should be enabled.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Allow devices to automatically update OS version
to Allow updates

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact to the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Target version' Is Set to Either 'Use latest version' or no older than n-3

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy configures what versions of ChromeOS are allowed in your organization.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Operating System Patch Management
Deploy Automated Operating System Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The target version for ChromeOS should be no less than the current version and the preceding three versions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Target version
to the current version of ChromeOS or one of the three previous versions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Roll back to target version' Is Set to 'Do not roll back OS'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls if ChromeOS versions can be rolled back to a pervious version.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: ChromeOS updates should not be rolled back due to possible security issues in previous versions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Roll back to target version
to Do not roll back OS

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This might cause an issue where a user has an extension that is not compatible with the newest version of ChromeOS.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Release channel' Is Set to 'Stable channel'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls what update release channel your organization's ChromeOS devices follow.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Standard user ChromeOS devices should be on the stable release channel.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Release channel
to Stable channel

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Rollout plan' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy configures how updates are rolled out in your organization.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Your organization should determine how update rollout happens.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Rollout plan
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Peer to peer' Is Set to 'Do not allow peer to peer auto update downloads'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether ChromeOS devices are allowed to update via peer-to-peer connections.

controls:safeguard.title: Disable Peer-to-peer Wireless Network Capabilities on Wireless Clients

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Updates should only be downloaded from Google's servers. Updating from another ChromeOS device could allow malicious content to be loaded.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Peer to peer
to Do not allow peer to peer auto update downloads

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact to the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Enforce updates' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy set controls how devices and users are handled when running a version of ChromeOS that is outside the required version(s).

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Operating System Patch Management
Deploy Automated Operating System Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This policy set should be configured to your organization's requirements.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Enforce updates
to match your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Only ChromeOS devices that are running a version outside the required version(s) would be affected.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Update downloads' Is Set to 'Use HTTPS for update downloads'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether updates can be dowloaded over HTTPS only or also with HTTP.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt All Sensitive Information in Transit

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Updates should only be downloaded on a secure connetion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Edit in legacy view
beside Auto-update settings

Set Update downloads
to Use HTTPS for update downloads

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Variations' Is Set to 'Enable Chrome variations'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Configuring this setting allows specifying which variations are allowed to be applied in Google Chrome. Variations provide a means for Google to offer modifications to Google Chrome without shipping a new version of the browser by selectively enabling or disabling already existing features.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Enable all variations
: Allows all variations to be applied to the browser (Default value).

Enable variations concerning critical fixes only
: Allows only variations considered critical security or stability fixes to be applied to Google Chrome.

Disable all variations
: Prevent all variations from being applied to the browser. Please note that this mode can potentially prevent the Google Chrome developers from providing critical security fixes in a timely manner and is thus not recommended.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enable all variations

NOTE:
Google strongly believes there is no added security benefit for turning this to critical fixes, as leaving it on increases the stability of the browser. Disabling variations can also prevent getting critical security updates in a timely manner.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google strongly recommends leaving this setting at the default (0 = Enable all variations), so fixes are gradually enabled (or if necessary, rapidly disabled) via the Chrome Variations framework.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Device update settings
, select Variations

Set Variations
to Enable Chrome variations

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Metrics reporting' Is Set to 'Never send metrics to Google'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy allows Google ChromeOS to report data back to Google. That data is made up of diagnostic data, crash reports, and usage metrics. It does not include web page URLs or any personal information except in crash reports. Depending on what was happening at the time of the crash, the crash report contains system information at the time of the crash and might contain webpage URLs or personal information.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Sending any data to an organization outside of your own, even aggregated, could lead to data leakage and should be avoided.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User and device reporting
, select Metrics reporting

Set Metrics reporting
