to Never send metrics to Google

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Device system log upload' Is Set to 'Enable device system log upload'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether system logs are uploaded to the management server. The default is unset or no system logs are reported.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: System logs should be uploaded to allow your organization's admins to monitor system logs.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User and device reporting
, select Device system log upload

Set Device system log upload
to Enable device system log upload

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Authenticated Proxy Traffic' Is Set to 'Block system traffic to go through a proxy with authentication'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether system traffic can go through an internet proxy server with authentication.

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy a Network Intrusion Detection Solution
Monitor and Block Unauthorized Network Traffic

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The default to block system traffic from going through a proxy with authentication keeps users from providing credentials to a possibly malicious proxy server.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User and device reporting
, select Authenticated Proxy Traffic

Set Authenticated Proxy Traffic
to Block system traffic from going through a proxy server with authentication

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This might block a device from access the internet from known good proxy servers.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Key Locker' Is Set to 'Use Key Locker with the encryption algorithm for user storage encryption'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether the AES Keylocker implementation is enabled for local user storage. This policy only applies to user homes which use dm-crypt for encryption. Legacy home users, those that do not use dm-crypt, are not supported and will default to AESNI (or disabled).

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: User home folders should be encrypted using AES Keylocker where applicable.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Other settings
, select Enable Key Locker

Set Enable Key Locker
to Use Key Locker with the encryption algorithm for user storage encryption, if supported

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: These configurations settings are for ChromeOS devices that are allowing guest sessions.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Managed guest session' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Managed guest sessions allow multiple users to share the same ChromeOS device without having to sign in to their Google Account. This should be used for ChromeOS devices as loaner devices or shared computers.
Managed guest sessions allow users to have a full browsing experience and access multiple websites in windowed mode but not in full-screen.

controls:safeguard.title: Define and Maintain Role-Based Access Control
Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If your organization uses guest sessions on Google ChromeOS, this policy should be configured to meet your organization's requirements.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under General
, select Managed guest session

Set Managed guest session
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Maximum user session length' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This control sets the length of time that a session can run before the user is logged out and the session is terminated. The user is shown in the system tray how much time is remaining before they will be automatically logged out.
The values are between 1 minute to 1440 minutes. If no value is set, then the system observes an unlimited session time.

While 60 minutes is a good operating baseline for the session, depending on your organization this may vary. For example, in K-12 a 24 hour (1440 minutes) session might be the best setting. Use the best setting for your organization's needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain an Inventory of Authentication Systems

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting a session length allows ChromeOS to not have a user session always signed in and cannot be immediately accessed by someone other than the user.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under General
, select Maximum user session length

Set Maximum session length
to your organization's parameters

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There could be impact to the user if they are unaware, or not checking, the session timer, and they are logged out.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Custom terms of service' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: An access warning informs the user that the system is reserved for authorized use only, and that the use of the system may be monitored.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: An access warning may reduce a casual attacker's tendency to target the system. Access warnings may also aid in the prosecution of an attacker by evincing the attacker's knowledge of the system's private status, acceptable use policy, and authorization requirements.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under General
, select Custom terms of service

Select a .txt
or .text
file from your local device that contains your organization's custom terms of service

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If users are not informed of their responsibilities, unapproved activities may occur. Users that are not approved for access may take the lack of a warning banner as implied consent to access.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Task Manager' Is Set to 'Block users from ending processes with the Chrome task manager'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The Task Manager in ChromeOS allows the user to kill any current processes running.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the Task Manager is enabled, a user can kill any running task, including those that your organization uses to manage the user of the device. Disabling that functionality removes this possibility.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Apps and extensions
, select Task manager

Set Task manager
to Block users from ending processes with the Chrome task manager

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If a task is no longer responding, the user would have to turn the device off and back on to kill that task.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Manifest v2 extension availability' Is Set to 'Enable force-installed manifest v2 extensions on the sign-in screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting controls extension management settings for Google Chrome, specifically v2 extensions. This policy setting is being sunsetted as Google develops the Manifest v3, but that rollout is currently postponed.
The policy can be configured to:

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Default browser behavior
Manifest v2 is disabled
Manifest v2 is enabled
Manifest v2 is enabled for forced extensions only

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Apply Host-based Firewalls or Port Filtering

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this to Forced Only will not allow users to install any additional v2 extensions, and all existing, non-forced, v2 extensions will be disabled.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Apps and extensions
, select Manifest v2 extension availability

Set Configuration
to Enable force-installed manifest v2 extensions on the sign-in screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users that use extensions regularly will have a set of them blocked, which will change their user experience.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Web Authentication requests on sites with broken TLS certificates' Is Set to 'Do not allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy setting controls the WebAuthn API and its interaction with sites that have a broken TLS certificate. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Do not allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates.
Allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will block the ability to authenticate to any website that does not have a valid TLS certificate since the identity of the site cannot be verified.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Security
, select Web Authentication requests on sites with broken TLS certificates

Set Web Authentication requests on sites with broken TLS certificates
to Do not allow WebAuthn API requests on sites with broken TLS certificates

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no user impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Insecure hashes in TLS handshakes' Is Set to 'Do not allow insecure hashes in TLS handshakes'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to allow legacy or insecure hashes during the TLS handshake. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Do Not Allow Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes
Allow Insecure Hashes in TLS Handshakes

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for InsecureHashesInTLSHandshakesEnabled
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy to disabled will block Google Chrome from using insecure hashes. Using insecure, or legacy, hashes could allow sensitive data to be exposed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Security
, select Insecure hashes in TLS handshakes

Set Insecure hashes in TLS handshakes
to Do not allow insecure hashes in TLS handshakes

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users would be blocked from visiting sites that do not support more secure hashes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Incognito mode' is set to 'Disallow incognito mode'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Specifies whether the user may open pages in Incognito mode in Google Chrome. The possible values are:

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Incognito mode available
Incognito mode disabled
Incognito mode forced

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Incognito mode disabled

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Incognito mode in Chrome gives you the choice to browse the internet without your activity being saved to your browser or device.

Allowing users to use the browser without any information being saved can hide evidence of malicious behaviors. This information may be important for a computer investigation, and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Incognito mode
to Disallow incognito mode

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to initiate Incognito mode for Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Browser history' is set to 'Always save browser history'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google ChromeOS is configured to save the browser history.
The recommended state for this setting is: Always save browser history

NOTE:
This setting will preserve browsing history that could contain a user's personal browsing history. Please make sure that this setting is in compliance with organizational policies.

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Browser history shall be saved as it may contain indicators of compromise.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Browser history
to Always save browser history

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'TLS encrypted ClientHello' Is 'Enable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for using Encrypted ClientHello (ECH). ECH is an extension to TLS and encrypts the initial handshake with a website that can only be decrypted by that website. Google Chrome may, or may not, use ECH based on 3 factors: server support, HTTPS DNS record availability, or rollout status. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Disable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment
Enable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for EncryptedClientHelloEnabled
is not changed from the default, it will behave as though it is enabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt All Sensitive Information in Transit

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Previously all handshakes were in the open and could expose sensitive information, such as the name of the website to which you are connecting. Setting this policy will allow Google Chrome to use an encrypted hello, or handshake, with a website where it is supported, thus not exposing sensitive information.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Security
, select TLS encrypted ClientHello

Set Configuration
to Enable the TLS Encrypted ClientHello experiment

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Strict MIME type checking for worker scripts' Is Set to 'Require a JavaScript MIME type for worker scripts'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for Google Chrome to upgrade to HTTPS from HTTP while navigating to certain sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Scripts for workers (Web Workers, Service Workers, etc.) use lax MIME type checking. Worker scripts with legacy MIME types, like text/ascii, will work.
Scripts for workers (Web Workers, Service Workers, etc.) require a JavaScript MIME type, like text/javascript. Worker scripts with legacy MIME types, like text/ascii, will be rejected.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: If the default is not changed, it will behave as if it is enabled.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy will require worker scripts to use more secure and strict JavaScript MIME types and ones with legacy MIME Types will be rejected.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Security
, select Strict MIME type checking for worker scripts

Set Configuration
to Require a JavaScript MIME type for worker scripts

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'File/directory picker without user gesture' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the ability for the file/directory picker to be called without user interaction.
If the value is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is disabled.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Apply Host-based Firewalls or Port Filtering

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting this policy would allow the URLs selected to call the the file or directory picker web APIs without any user gesture/interaction. This policy does not need to be set for this reason.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Security
, select File/directory picker without user gesture
Remove all URLs from Allow file or directory picker APIs to be called without prior user gesture

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Disabling this policy should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Media picker without user gesture' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls if URLs or hostname patterns can display the media picker for a screen capture without user interaction.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: To call the media picker, a prior gesture from a user needs to be required. If there is no user gesture then the call will fail.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Security
, select Media picker without user gesture
Remove all URLs from Allow screen capture without prior user gesture

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Remote access clients' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls what client domain names have remote access to the client ChromeOS devices in your organization. Only a connection from one of the specified client domains can connect to the client device.

Leaving the policy empty (or unsetting it) applies the default policy for the connection type. For remote assistance, this allows clients from any domain to connect to the host. For anytime remote access, only the host owner can connect.

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Remote Devices Utilize a VPN and are Connecting to an Enterprises AAA Infrastructure
Maintain an Inventory of Network Boundaries

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
Your organization should configure Remote access clients
for the client domains in your organization that have access to your client devices.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Remote access
, select Remote access clients

Set Remote access client domain
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Remote access hosts' is set with a domain defined in 'Remote access host domain'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows the configuration of a list of domains that are allowed to access the user's system. When enabled, remote systems can only connect if they are one of the specified domains listed.
Setting this to an empty list (Disabled) allows remote systems from any domain to connect to this user's system.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1) and at least one domain set.

NOTE:
The list of domains is organization-specific.

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote assistance connections shall be restricted.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Remote access
, select Remote access hosts

Set Remote access host domain
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, only systems from the specified domains can connect to the user's system.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Firewall traversal' is set to 'Disable the use of relay servers'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows the use of relay servers when clients are trying to connect to this machine and a direct connection is not available.

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: The use of relay servers by the remote access host is not allowed
The use of relay servers by the remote access host is allowed

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: The use of relay servers by the remote access host is not allowed

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Relay servers shall not be used to circumvent firewall restrictions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Remote access
, select Firewall traversal

Set Firewall traversal
to Disable the use of relay servers

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, remote clients can not use relay servers to connect to this machine.

NOTE:
Setting this to Disabled doesn't turn remote access off, but only allows connections from the same network (not NAT traversal or relay).

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Remote support connections' is set to 'Prevent remote support connections'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This is a setting for Chrome Remote desktop. If this setting is Disabled, the remote access host service cannot be started or configured to accept incoming connections.

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Prevent remote access connections to this machine
Allow remote access connections to this machine

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Prevent remote access connections to this machine

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Only approved remote access systems should be used.

NOTE:
If Chrome Remote Desktop is approved and required for use, then this setting can be ignored.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Remote access
, select Remote support connections

Set Remote support connections
to Prevent remote support connections

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting will disable Chrome Remote Desktop. In general, Chrome Remote Desktop is not used by most businesses, so disabling it should have no impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Show sign-out button in tray' Is Set to 'Show sign-out button in tray'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Show sign-out button in tray
policy controls whether a sign-out button is in the system tray while the screen is not locked and the session is active.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling the sign-out button in the system tray would allow a user to quickly log out of a session in a situation where there may be malicious actors trying to 'shoulder-surf' or to capture data from the user's screen.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Session settings
, select Show sign-out button in tray

Set Show sign-out button in tray
to Show sign-out button in tray

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This would have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Proxy mode' is Not Set to 'Always auto detect the proxy'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the functionality to configure the proxy settings by automatic discovery using WPAD (Web Proxy Auto-Discovery Protocol). Setting this configures the proxy settings for Chrome and ARC-apps, which ignore all proxy-related options specified from the command line.

Disabled
(0): Lets users choose their proxy settings.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
and the value of ProxyMode
is not set to auto_detect

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy Application Layer Filtering Proxy Server

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Attackers may abuse the WPAD auto-config functionality to supply computers with a PAC file that specifies a rogue web proxy under their control.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Proxy mode
to a setting other than Always auto detect the proxy

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If the policy is enabled, the proxy configuration will no longer be discovered using WPAD.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Ignore proxy on captive portals' Is Set to 'Keep policies for captive portal pages'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy configures the ability for Google ChromeOS to bypass any proxy for captive portal authentication.

If enabled, these authentication webpages, starting from the captive portal sign-in page until Chrome detects a successful internet connection, will open in a separate window and ignore all policy settings and restrictions for the current user.
If disabled, any captive portal authentication pages are shown in a new browser tab that uses the current user's proxy settings.
This policy only takes effect if a proxy is set up (by policy, extension, or the user in chrome://settings).

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Network Architecture
Maintain an Inventory of Authorized Wireless Access Points

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling captive portal sites to bypass proxy settings could grant access to the system from a malicious (or misconfigured) captive portal site. Setting the policy to disabled forces all sites, including captive portal sites, to use the configured proxy settings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Network
, select Ignore proxy on captive portals

Set Ignore proxy on captive portals
to Keep policies for captive portal pages

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This may impact a user's access to certain captive portal sites that do not work with the configured proxy server.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SSL error override' is set to 'Block users from clicking through SSL warnings'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether a user is able to proceed to a webpage when an invalid SSL certificate warning has occurred.
The recommended state for this setting is: Block users from clicking through SSL warnings

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Sites protected by SSL should always be recognized as valid in the web browser. Allowing a user to make the decision as to whether there appears to be an invalid certificate could open an organization up to users visiting a site that is otherwise not secure and/or malicious in nature.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Network
, select SSL error override

Set SSL error override
to Block users from clicking through SSL warnings

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to click past the invalid certificate error to view the website.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Globally scoped HTTP authentication cache' is set to 'HTTP authentication credentials are scoped to top-level sites'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether HTTP auth credentials may be automatically used in the context of another web site visited in Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: HTTP authentication credentials are scoped to top-level sites

NOTE:
This setting is intended to give enterprises depending on the legacy behavior a chance to update their login procedures and will be removed in the future.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing HTTP auth credentials to be shared without the user's consent could lead to a user sharing sensitive information without their knowledge. Enabling this setting could also lead to some types of cross-site attacks that would allow users to be tracked across sites without the use of cookies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Network
, select Globally scoped HTTP authentication cache

Set Globally scoped HTTP authentication cache
to HTTP authentication credentials are scoped to top-level sites

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'DNS over HTTPS' is set to 'Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This controls the mode of the DNS-over-HTTPS resolver. Please note that this setting will only set the default mode for each query. The mode may be overridden for special types of queries, such as requests to resolve a DNS-over-HTTPS server hostname.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disable DNS-over-HTTPS
(off)

Enable DNS-over-HTTPS with insecure fallback
(automatic) - Enable DNS-over-HTTPS queries first if a DNS-over-HTTPS server is available and may fallback to sending insecure queries on error.

Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback
(secure) - Only send DNS-over-HTTPS queries and will fail to resolve on error.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback
(secure)

Note:
When enabling this policy, it is recommended to also configure the DnsOverHttpsTemplates
policy so that the URI templates are set. You can find out more information on the DnsOverHttpsTemplates
enterprise policy site
.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce on Data Handling Best Practices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: DNS over HTTPS (DOH) has a couple primary benefits:

xhtml:li.xhtml:p: Encrypting DNS name resolution traffic helps to hide your online activities, since DoH hides the name resolution requests from the ISP and from anyone listening on intermediary networks.
DoH also helps to prevent DNS spoofing and man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Network
, select DNS over HTTPS

Set DNS over HTTPS
to Enable DNS-over-HTTPS without insecure fallback

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Not all DNS providers support DOH, so choice is limited. Also, Enterprises sometimes monitor DNS requests to block access to malicious or inappropriate sites. DNS monitoring can also sometimes be used to detect malware attempting to "phone home." Because DoH encrypts name resolution requests, it can create a security monitoring blind spot.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'SharedArrayBuffer' Is Set to 'Prevent sites that are not cross-origin isolated from using SharedArrayBuffers'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether SharedArrayBuffers can be used in a non cross-origin-isolated context.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Sites that are not cross-origin isolated need to be prevented from using the SharedArrayBuffers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set SharedArrayBuffer
to Prevent sites that are not cross-origin isolated from using SharedArrayBuffers

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'HSTS policy bypass list' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows a list of names to be specified that will be exempt from HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) policy checks, then potentially upgraded from http:// to https://.
The recommended state for this setting is not configured.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing hostnames to be exempt from HSTS checks could allow for protocol downgrade attacks and cookie hijackings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Network
, select HSTS policy bypass list
Remove all hostnames from List of hostnames that will bypass the HSTS policy check

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'DNS interception checks enabled' is set to 'Perform DNS interception checks'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines whether a local switch is configured for DNS interception checks. These checks attempt to discover if the browser is behind a proxy that redirects unknown host names.
The recommended state for this setting is: Perform DNS interception checks

NOTE:
This detection might not be necessary in an enterprise environment where the network configuration is known. It can be disabled to avoid additional DNS and HTTP traffic on startup and each DNS configuration change.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Unsuccessful Administrative Account Login

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling these checks could potentially allow DNS hijacking and poisoning.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Network
, select DNS interception checks enabled

Set DNS interception checks enabled
to Perform DNS interception checks

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SafeSearch and Restricted Mode' is set to 'Always use Safe Search for Google Web Search queries'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting ensures that web search results with Google are performed with SafeSearch set to always active. Disabled means SafeSearch in Google Search is not enforced.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
(1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content, including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Content
, select SafeSearch and Restricted Mode

Set SafeSearch and Restricted Mode
to Always use Safe Search for Google Web Search queries

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
User search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos, and images will not be shown.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Clipboard' Is Set to 'Do not allow any site to use the clipboard site permission'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls the defaults for clipboard permission access from sites. It can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Allow the user to decide
Allow sites to ask the user to grant the clipboard site permission
Do not allow any site to use the clipboard site permission

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The clipboard stores data, text, and images that are shared between all applications. An organization would disable clipboard access to restrict sites from reading the contents of the clipboard when visiting.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Clipboard
to Do not allow any site to use the clipboard site permission

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Not allowing sites to have access to the clipboard permission can cause issues with formatting or access to needed images on the clipboard.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Auto open downloaded files' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether specified file types are allowed to auto open on download. It also controls specified URLs to allow those specified file types to auto open when they are downloaded from those URLs.

controls:safeguard.title: Disable Autorun and Autoplay for Removable Media
Configure Devices Not To Auto-run Content

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: No file types should not be allowed to auto open and the user is required to interact with every downloaded file they wish to open.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Content
, select Auto open downloaded files
Remove all file types from Auto open file types
Remove all URLs from Auto open URLs

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There is no impact to the user

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Control use of insecure content exceptions' is set to 'Do not allow any site to load mixed content'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Setting controls whether users can add exceptions to allow mixed content for specific sites.

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Do not allow any site to load mixed content
Allow users to add exceptions to allow mixed content

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to load mixed content

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing mixed (secure / insecure) content from a site can lead to malicious content being loaded. Mixed content occurs if the initial request is secure over HTTPS, but HTTPS and HTTP content is subsequently loaded to display the web page. HTTPS content is secure. HTTP content is insecure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Content
, select Control use of insecure content exceptions

Set Control use of insecure content exceptions
to Do not allow any site to load mixed content

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to mix content.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow insecure content on these sites' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy specifies a list of pages that can display active mixed content, such as scripts and iframes. Also, Chrome does not automatically upgrade optionally-blockable, or passive, mixed content from HTTP to HTTPS. Passive mixed content includes images, audio, and video.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Devices Not To Auto-run Content

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: There needs to be no URLs in the configured settings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Content
, select Allow insecure content on these sites
Remove all URLs from Allow insecure content on these sites

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There should be no impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Requests from insecure websites to more-private network endpoints' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls whether websites are allowed to make requests to more private network endpoints in an insecure manner.
When this policy is set to true, all Private Network Access checks are disabled for all origins. This may allow attackers to perform CSRF attacks on private network servers.

controls:safeguard.title: Deploy a Network Intrusion Detection Solution
Monitor and Block Unauthorized Network Traffic

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This policy should not be configured.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Content
, select Requests from insecure websites to more-private network endpoints
Remove all URLs from Requests from insecure websites to more-private network endpoints

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
The only impact would be accessing insecure websites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection' is set to 'Data collection is never active'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers URL-keyed anonymized data collection as a feature. This sends URLs of pages the user visits to Google to optimize its services.

The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled
(0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymized data collection shall be disabled, since it is unclear which specific information is sent to Google.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Network
, select Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection

Set Enable URL-keyed anonymized data collection
to Data collection is never active

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Anonymized data will not be sent to Google to help optimize its services.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow local file access to file:// URLs on these sites in the PDF Viewer' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This setting will allow specified URLs to access file://
URLs in the PDF Viewer. By default all domains are blocked from accessing file://
URLs in the PDF Viewer.

controls:safeguard.title: Train Workforce Members on Recognizing and Reporting Security Incidents

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Blocking all domains, or a restricted list of domains, from opening a downloaded PDF file blocks the possibility of a malicious file being masked as a PDF. It could also block unknown or malicious code contained within the PDF that would run upon immediate opening within a browser tab.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Content
, select Allow local file access to file:// URLs on these sites in the PDF Viewer
Remove all URLs from Allowed URLs

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be required to open PDF files manually in the PDF Viewer or in the organization's PDF viewing application.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Idle settings' Is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: A locking screen saver is one of the standard security controls to limit access to a computer and the current user's session when the computer is temporarily unused or unattended.

controls:safeguard.title: Configure Automatic Session Locking on Enterprise Assets
Maintain an Inventory of Authentication Systems

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting an inactivity interval for the screen saver prevents unauthorized persons from viewing a system left unattended for an extensive period of time.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Power and shutdown
, select Idle settings

Set Idle settings
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If the screen saver is not set, users may leave the computer available for an unauthorized person to access information.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has an API which allows access to connected USB devices from the browser

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Do not allow any site to request access
Allow sites to ask the user for access
Allow the user to decide if sites can ask

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is Do not allow any site to request access
.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: WebUSB is opening the doors for sophisticated phishing attacks that could bypass hardware-based two-factor authentication devices (e.g. Yubikey devices).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set WebUSB API
to Do not allow any site to request access

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is configured, websites can no longer access connected USB devices via the API (this includes web cameras, headphones, and other USB devices) which could also prevent some two factor authentication (2FA) USB devices from working properly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Web Serial API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Web Serial API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of the system serial port.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Allow the user to decide (default) Lets websites ask for access, but users can change this setting.
Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to serial ports via the Web Serial API Lets websites ask the user for access to serial ports.
Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Web Serial API

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Serial API

NOTE:
If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls
, SerialAskForUrls
and SerialBlockedForUrls
settings. For example, SerialAllowAllPortsForUrls
can be used to allow serial port access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system serial ports may prevent malicious sites from using these ports and accessing the devices attached.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Hardware
, select Web Serial API

Set Web Serial API
to Do not allow any site to request access to serial ports via the Web Serial API

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Privacy screen' Is Set to 'Always enable the privacy screen'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The privacy screen for ChromeOS is a feature that activates when the user walks away from the Chromebook. If activated, the screen will dim after 10 seconds. It can also keep the screen awake while the user is in front of the Chromebook even if they are not interacting with the device.
This policy requires a built in webcam and for ChromeOS devices with an integrated electronic privacy screen.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Setting the operating system to automatically dim and lock the screen when the user moves away from the device protects potentially sensitive user data.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Privacy screen
to Always enable the privacy screen

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This should have no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Audio input (microphone)' is set to 'Disable audio input'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to audio capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disable audio input
- turns off prompts

Prompt user to allow each time
- users get prompted for audio capture access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
NOTE:
The setting affects all audio input (not just the built-in microphone).
The recommended state for this setting is: Disable audio input

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny audio capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing audio capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Audio input (microphone)
to Disable audio input

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for audio devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites to which access will be allowed, configuration of the AudioCaptureAllowedUrls
setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Video input (camera)' is set to 'Disable camera input for websites and apps'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows administrators to set whether the end-user is prompted for access to video capture devices.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Disable camera input for websites and apps
- turns off prompts

Enable camera input for website and apps
- users get prompted for video capture access

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
NOTE:
The setting affects all video input (not just the built-in camera).

The recommended state for this setting is Disable camera input for websites and apps
.

controls:safeguard.title: Log and Alert on Changes to Administrative Group Membership

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user having the ability to allow or deny video capture for websites in Google Chrome could open an organization up to a malicious site that may capture proprietary information through the browser. By limiting or disallowing video capture, it removes the end-user's discretion, leaving it up to the organization which sites are allowed to use this ability.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Configuration
to Disable camera input for websites and apps

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If you disable this setting, users will not be prompted for video devices when using websites which may need this access, such as a web-based conferencing system. If there are sites to which access will be allowed, configuration of the VideoCaptureAllowedUrls
setting will be necessary.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Sensors' is set to 'Do not allow any site to access sensors'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls website access and use of system sensors such as motion and light.

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Allow sites to access sensors
Do not allow any site to access sensors

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is Do not allow any site to access sensors
.

NOTE:
If more granular control is needed (per website) then this setting can be used in combination with the SensorsAllowedForUrls
and SensorsBlockedForUrls
settings. For example, SensorsAllowedForUrls
can be used to allow sensor access to specific sites. Please see the references below for more information.

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing access to system sensors may prevent malicious sites from using these sensors for user profiling (OpSec).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Set Sensors
to Do not allow any site to access sensors

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting would also prevent legitimate sites from accessing it as well.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'USB device detected notification' Is Set to 'Show notifications when USB devices are detected'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls notifications when USB devices are connected to a ChromeOS device. By default, notifications are shown when a USB device is connected. The settings are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Show notifications when USB devices are detected
- notifications are shown when a USB device is connected

Do not show notifications when USB devices are detected
- notifications are not shown when a USB device is connected

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A user should be alerted if a USB device is connected to their Google ChromeOS device. This allows the user to be notified if a device is connected without their knowledge or permission.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Hardware
, select USB device detected notification

Set USB device detected notification
to Show notifications when USB devices are detected

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - this is the default.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Safe Browsing protection' is set to 'Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode' and 'Allow higher-protection proxied lookups'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Control whether Google Chrome's Safe Browsing feature is enabled and the mode in which it operates. If you set this setting as mandatory, users cannot change or override the Safe Browsing setting in Google Chrome.
If this setting is left not set, Safe Browsing will operate in Standard Protection mode, but users can change this setting.

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Allow the user to decide
Safe Browsing is never active
Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode
Safe Browsing is active in the enhanced mode. This mode provides better security, but requires sharing more browsing information with Google

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is: Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode
or higher.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Safe Browsing will help protect users from a variety of malicious and fraudulent sites or from downloading dangerous files.

NOTE:
Google recommends using Enhanced Safe Browsing Mode. Turning on Enhanced Safe Browsing will substantially increase protection from dangerous websites and downloads, but will share more data with Google.
For more details, please refer to the items in the References section below.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Chrome Safe Browsing
, select Safe Browsing protection

Set Safe Browsing Protection Level
to Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode

Set Allow Safe Browsing's standard protection mode to send partial hashes of URLs to Google
to Allow higher-protection proxied lookups

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
There is no impact on the user.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Download restrictions' is set to 'Block malicious downloads'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can block certain types of downloads, and won't let users bypass the security warnings, depending on the classification of Safe Browsing.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
No special restrictions
(Default)

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Block malicious downloads
Block malicious downloads and dangerous file types
Block malicious downloads, uncommon or unwanted downloads and dangerous file types
Block all downloads

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is Block malicious downloads
.

NOTE:
These restrictions apply to downloads triggered from webpage content, as well as the "Download link..." menu option. They don't apply to the download of the currently displayed page or to saving as PDF from the printing options.

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Backups Have At least One Non-Continuously Addressable Destination

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from downloading malicious file types and shall not be able to bypass security warnings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Chrome Safe Browsing
, select Download restrictions

Set Download restrictions
to Block malicious downloads

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled, all downloads are allowed, except for those that carry Safe Browsing warnings. These are downloads that have been identified as risky or from a risky source by the Google Safe Browsing Global intelligence engine
.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable bypassing Safe Browsing warnings' is set to 'Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google provides the Safe Browsing service. It shows a warning page when users navigate to sites that are flagged as potentially malicious. The settings for the policy are:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li:
Allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning
(Default)

xhtml:li.xhtml:span: Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The recommended state for this setting is Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning
.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious web pages are widely spread on the internet and pose the most significant threat to the user today. Users shall be prevented from navigating to potentially malicious web content.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Chrome Safe Browsing
, select Disable bypassing Safe Browsing warnings

Set Disable bypassing Safe Browsing warnings
to Do not allow user to bypass Safe Browsing warning

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents users from proceeding anyway from the warning page to the malicious site. In some cases legitimate sites could be blocked and users would be prevented from accessing.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'SafeSites URL filter' is set to 'Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use the Google Safe Search API to classify URLs as pornographic or not.
The recommended state for this setting is: Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Chrome Safe Browsing
, select SafeSites URL filter

Set SafeSites URL filter
to Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users' search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos, and images will not be shown.

NOTE:
Using Googles Safe Search API may leak information which is typed/pasted by mistake into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains' is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting prevents the display of lookalike URL warnings on the sites listed. These warnings are typically shown on sites that Google Chrome believes might be trying to spoof another site with which the user is familiar.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Look-alike domains are intentionally misleading to give users the false impression that theyre interacting with trusted brands, leading to significant reputation damage, financial losses, and data compromise for established enterprises.

In addition, this technique is commonly used to host phishing sites, and often leads to account takeover attacks. Users are prompted to enter their credentials on a fake website, and scammers take control of their online accounts with little effort to engage in fraudulent activity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Chrome Safe Browsing
, select Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains
Remove all URLs from Allowlisted Domains

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

NOTE:
The only real impact is possible user annoyance if they are going to a legitimate site that is falsely considered fraudulent (a rare occurrence). This can be handled by adding the site to the allowlist and/or notifying Google of the false finding.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Data controls reporting' Is Set to 'Enable reporting of data control events'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
This policy controls real-time reporting when the data leak prevention event triggers. This is disabled by default. Setting this policy to Enable reporting of data leak prevention events
will switch on real-time reporting of data leak prevention events. Setting this policy to Disable reporting of data leak prevention events
or leaving it unset will switch off the reporting.

Note:
Data control rules are defined on the rules page which centralizes the creation and management of all rules. Please create and modify any Chrome action data control rules from there.
To access the rules page follow these instructions:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
Create rules based on your organization's requirements. Refer to the Google Enterprise Help Center for the Set ChromeOS data controls documents
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Data controls
, select Data controls reporting

Set Data controls reporting
to Enable reporting of data leak prevention events

Select Rules
in the left sidebar menu

Set Rules
to your organization's requirements

xhtml:p.xhtml:p:
Note:
To set the appropriate rules for your organization, refer to the Google Enterprise Help Center for the Set ChromeOS data controls documents
.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allowed types of apps and extensions' is set to 'Extension', 'Hosted App', 'Chrome Packaged App', and 'Theme'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which app/extension types are allowed.

Disabled
(0): Results in no restrictions on the acceptable extension and app types.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with the values of extension
, hosted_app
, platform_app
, theme
.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: App or extension types that could be misused or are deprecated shall no longer be installed.

NOTE:
Google has removed support for Chrome Apps which includes the types hosted_app and platform_app. The blog post indicates that these types will require a setting to be enabled for continued use through June 2022.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Additional Settings

Set Allowed types of apps and extensions
to Extension
, Hosted App
, Chrome Packaged App
, and Theme

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Extensions already installed will be removed if its type is denylisted and the extension itself is not allowlisted.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'App and extension install sources' Is Not Set

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which extensions the users can NOT install. Extensions already installed will be removed if blocklisted.

Disabled
(0): then the user can install any extension in Google Chrome.

The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled
with a value of *

NOTE:
Chrome does offer a more granular permission-based configuration called Extension management settings
if blocklisting all extensions is too aggressive, which allows an organization to drill down to the exact permissions that they want to lock down. The extensions management settings require more coordination and effort to understand what the security requirements are to block site and device permissions globally, as well as more IT management to deploy. The benefit would be allowing access to more extensions to their end-users. See link in reference section.

NOTE:
If Chrome Cleanup is Disabled, users may want to configure the extension blocklist instead of using the Extension Management option. Chrome Cleanup can help protect against malicious extensions when paired with the Extension Management setting.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p:
This can be used to block extensions that could potentially allow remote control of the system through the browser. If there are extensions needed for securing the browser or for enterprise use, these can be enabled by configuring either the setting Configure extension installation allowlist
or the setting Extension management settings
.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Additional Settings
Remove all URLs from App and extension install sources

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Any installed extension will be removed unless it is specified on the extension allowlist. If an organization is using any approved password managers, ensure that the extension is added to the allowlist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Chrome Web Store unpublished extensions' Is Set to 'Disable unpublished extensions'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy disables any extensions in Google Chrome that were downloaded from the Chrome Web Store and are now unpublished. The policy can be configured to either:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Enabled (0): Allow unpublished extensions
Disabled (1): Disable unpublished extensions

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
If the value for ExtensionUnpublishedAvailability
is not changed from the default, it will behave as if it is enabled.

Note:
Off-store extensions such as unpacked extensions installed using developer mode and extensions installed using the command-line switch are ignored. Force-installed extensions that are self-hosted are ignored. All version-pinned extensions are also ignored.

controls:safeguard.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process
Apply Host-based Firewalls or Port Filtering

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling unpublished extensions will remove the ability to run any extensions that are no longer being updated or patched.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User & browser settings
, select Additional Settings

Set Chrome Web Store unpublished extensions
to Disable unpublished extensions

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This may disable extensions commonly used by users in your organization.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The Google Workspace sub-section of the Google Workspace Admin Console.
Gmail settings.
Set name formats. Enable user preferences such as themes, read receipts, and email delegation.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure users cannot delegate access to their mailbox

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Mail delegation allows the delegate to read, send, and delete messages on their behalf. For example, a manager can delegate Gmail access to another person in their organization, such as an administrative assistant.

controls:safeguard.title: Protect Information through Access Control Lists

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Only administrators should be able to delegate access to a user's mailboxes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under User Settings
- Mail delegation
, set Let users delegate access to their mailbox to other users in the domain
to unchecked

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Existing delegations will be hidden when this feature is disabled.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Configure email and spam safety features.
Additional policies to protect against malware in emails.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure protection against encrypted attachments from untrusted senders is enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: As a Google Workspace administrator, you can protect incoming mail against phishing and harmful software (malware). You can also choose what action to take based on the type of threat detected.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: You should protect your users from potentially malicious attachments.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Safety
- Attachments
, set Protect against encrypted attachments from untrusted senders
to checked

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be warned when they receive an encrypted attachment from an untrusted sender.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure protection against attachments with scripts from untrusted senders is enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: As a Google Workspace administrator, you can protect incoming mail against phishing and harmful software (malware). You can also choose what action to take based on the type of threat detected.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: You should protect your users from potentially malicious attachments.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To verify this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Safety
- Attachments
, set Protect against attachments with scripts from untrusted senders
to checked

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be warned when they receive an attachment with scripts from an untrusted sender.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure protection against anomalous attachment types in emails is enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: As a Google Workspace administrator, you can protect incoming mail against phishing and harmful software (malware). You can also choose what action to take based on the type of threat detected.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: You should protect your users from potentially malicious attachments.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Safety
- Attachments
, set Protect against anomalous attachment types in emails
to checked

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be warned when they receive an anomalous attachment.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Additional settings to prevent email phishing due to links and external images.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure link identification behind shortened URLs is enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Identify links behind short URLs, and display a warning when you click links to untrusted domains.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: You should protect your users from potentially malicious links.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To verify this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Safety
- Links and external images
, set Identify links behind shortened URLs
to checked

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be warned when they click links to untrusted domains.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure scan linked images for malicious content is enabled

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Scan linked images for malicious content, and display a warning when you click links to untrusted domains.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: You should protect your users from potentially malicious links.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Safety
- Links and external images
, set Scan linked images
to checked

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be warned when they click links to untrusted domains.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure warning prompt is shown for any click on links to untrusted domains

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Display a warning when you click links to untrusted domains.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: You should protect your users from potentially malicious links.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To configure this setting via the Google Workspace Admin Console:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li:
Log in to https://admin.google.com
as an administrator

Under Safety
- Links and external images
, set Show warning prompt for any click on links to untrusted domains
is checked

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will be warned when they click links to untrusted domains.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p:
The Rules
section of Google Workspace is where your organization can set data control rules. There is no specific guidance around what rules your organization should create, but there should be rules based on what your security team has decided to monitor. Refer to the Google Enterprise Help Center for the Set ChromeOS data controls documents
.

metadata.title: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'
metadata.description: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'

external_variable.comment: This value is used in Rule: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API' for the registry data type
This value is used in Rule: (L2) Ensure 'WebUSB API' is set to 'Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API' for the registry value
